data.name: Migrants' Theatre

info.description: We are young adults from Slovakia, volunteering artists, passionate for theatre. When living in London, we came through various experience, so we decided to capture feelings of different stages of our life in London in a theatre production. We were able to give voice to numerous Europeans migrating between their home countries and United Kingdom. We revealed stories that often stay hidden under the mask of a hardworking lifestyle. People of different nationalities approached us after one of our first stage shows and encouraged us to continue showing what is the real cost of abandoning the home country, although within the supposed familiar European context. Our finished production was delivered in April 2016 and we have performed five times since then. As volunteers, we do not expect to make money for what we do but we would like to balance our investments with the incomme/donations. Because of the topic MIGRANTS´ RHAPSODY being so generally resonating with European countries, we found audiences both in UK and abroad. That added an extra cost to our travel expenses. With your help, we will be able to continue performing.  Sme mladí ľudia zo Slovenska, žijúci v Londýne. Máme pozitívny vzťah k umeniu a k divadlu zvlášť, preto sme súčasťou dobrovoľného divadelného združenia SLOVENSKÉ KOMUNITNÉ DIVADLO V LONDÝNE. Pred takmer dvoma rokmi sme sa rozhodli zachytiť v divadelnej hre všetko, čo sme zažili počas našej londýnskej Odysey. Výsledkom našich snáh sa stala jedinečná, sedemdesiatminútová divadelná hra Migrantská rapsódia. Diváci z rozličných európskych krajín za nami prichádzali po predstavení prvej verzie hry a presviedčali nás o tom, že máme pokračovať, pretože zobrazujeme skúsenosť, ktorá spája všetkých presídlencov bez výnimky. Rozhodli sme sa teda hru sprístupniť komukoľvek a naskúšali sme ju v oboch jazykoch - v slovenčine aj v angličtine. Od apríla 2016 hráme pre britských aj zahraničných divákov, krajanov aj medzinárodné obecenstvo. Ako nezisková skupina neočakávame viac, než návrat nákladov, no kvôli cestovaniu sa naše investície do projektu mierne navýšili. Preto aktivujeme verejnú zbierku. Svojím príspevkom podporíte nielen šírenie súčasného umenia, ale aj tvorivosť a kultúrnu reprezentáciu Slovákov, žijúcich v zahraničí. Ďakujeme!EXAMPLE of TRAVEL EXPENSESA return ticket from London to Nitra - 7 x £50 = £350                               Return flight tickets from London to Prague - 3 x £70 = £210                   Flight tickets from Prague to London -  4 x £40 = £160                             Train tickets from Slovak cities to Prague - 4 x 20€ = 80€                         Train tickets from London to Brussels - 7 x £80 = £560TOTAL: £1,490, 80€LIST of SHOWSPast Productions in 2016:/17th April 229 Venue London, UK – premiere/30th April Alexander Duchnovic Theatre, Presov, Slovakia (twice) 13th June  Voyager Academy Peterborough, UK17th July Don Bosco College, London Battersea, UK	/12th August	 Slovak House, Prague, Czech Republic/13th August 	Slovak House, Prague, Czech Republic/Upcoming Events in 2016:  24th September: Festival Divadelná Nitra (Theatrical Nitra), Slovakia1st October: Pegg Theatre Studio, Bristol, UK14th October: Embassy of Slovakia, London, UK16th October: Yoxhall Village Hall, Haslington Crewe, UKNovember: Embassy of Slovakia, Brussels, Belgium - date TBNovember: The Middlesex University Studio – date TBC
info.risks and challenges: The greatest challenge for our theatre group was to keep ourselves motivated and to follow our initial vision after some of our members gave up the devising. Also, we often had to overcome tiredness on Sunday afternoons and replace the relax by pushing ourselves to creative thinking./In addition, this production takes us to new places and audiences which challenges our modest budget. We really hope to catch up with the expenses by the help of Kickstarter./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: Young adult theatre makers from London are raising money to cover costs for touring with their current production Migrants´ Rhapsody.

data.name: At Swim, Two Boys

info.description: At Swim, Two Boys is a novel written by Jamie O’Neil and adapted for the stage by Tim Scott. It tells the story of Dun Laoghaire boys Jim and Doyler and their friendship on the brink of Irish independence. The play will be performed from the 6-18 June in the Samuel Beckett Theatre. The project has been in the making for the last couple of moths and even before the first performance we have been offered to extend the run by a week. While we are thrilled about this, it poses some financial problems, as we had not taken a second week into consideration in the budget. Most of the set, the costumes and some of lights need to be hired and the second week doubles these expenses. In order to cover them we would kindly ask for your help. Your donation will contribute considerably to the quality of the production.
info.risks and challenges: This campaign is the safest and quickest way to raise a small amount of money to boost our budget and allow the production to continue as planned. Without the extra money we will have to scale down the set, the costumes, and the lighting, which will have a huge impact on the visual quality of the play. By supporting us you will make it a more enjoyable and memorable experience for yourself and for the participants./The money will be well spent and we would be very happy for you to convince yourself of that by attending one of our performances./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: The play tells the story of Jim and Doyler and their friendship on the brink of Irish independence.

data.name: Infectious, love at the end of the 21st century!

info.description: The proposed activity is the development and performance/of a new play-Infectious. Infectious/was written by Meghan Leslie in response to many topical stories she had read/around the suggestion of there being a future potential for humans, to become/resistant to antibiotics. Scary! The writing process began through exploring these/questions; what would you do if you couldn't touch another person? Couldn't kiss another person? What would society/look like if humans were no longer immune to certain fatal viruses? How would we live? Who would we love? With Ebola in 2014, the/people in Sierra Leone are now following the “don’t touch rule.” What would this be like in a contemporary society/if people couldn't touch, if they couldn't hug, fight, or kiss? What would our/communities look like over time, how would they act? Through the development/and performance of this play, Welded Theatre aims to explore this idea with the/help of a group of diverse actors that include professional actors originally/from Slovenia, Ireland, and Canada. We hope to achieve engagement with our/actors and audience, by immersing them into this play and our unique artistic/processes. Allowing the audience to see exactly what their near future might/look like.The play has been picked up by The Wardrobe Theatre in Bristol and programmed into their Spring Season brochure. The Wardrobe Theatre is a very respected performance space that is known for supporting up and coming companies like ours within the region. Their website gets about 3000 visits per month and they are cross promoters for larger theatre houses like The Bristol Old Vic. Welded Theatre is committed to providing/accessible and affordable theatre arts events to it audiences by setting/realistic guidelines for our financial future. By following our personal code/of financial conduct, we will set realistic budgets for ourselves on each/production. For the production of Infectious/we have managed to keep our costs as low as possible, without sacrificing our artistic goals. This where you come in.The founding members of Welded Theatre have independently given over a set amount money as a start up for the theatre company. What we need from you is a little support in kind to add extra coins to our pockets to reach our maximum funding goal for this production.This money will go towards all the bits and pieces from which we will build this production. You will literally be buying items such as- a few cups of tea and lunch during the rehearsals for the cast, or a few more lighting gels to help with our lighting design, extra time in a rehearsal space, cleaning products, a costume, extra pieces of set, or a free ticket to the show for a student.   To find out more about our company and background please visit: http://www.weldedtheatre.com/
info.risks and challenges: There are always risks and challenges with anything, especially when it comes to the performance arts. Government budget cuts to the arts for one thing! Welded Theatre was formed with a clear artistic code of ethos (please see our website) in order to survive in this economic climate and to allow us be able to bring our artistry to the public. Infectious, is our first play that will be produced professionally in conjunction with a major theatre house. This is our moment to put everything we have learned, practiced, and experienced to the test./We believe so much in this project that we chose Kickstarter for its "all or nothing rule" Edmund & Meghan ARE ALL IN on this project, and so we are asking you to join us to. We have to reach the total pledge goal in order to receive any of the pledge./Here is a little bit of background information from our production manager who will be overseeing all of our income and expenditure; just so you know who will be handling your pledges./Over the last 8 years Edmund McKay has been freelancing as Production Manager for the Arts. The projects he has managed ranged in budgets from £3,000-£20,000; for art organisations such as Earthfall Dance, Kompany Malakhi and Moving Dust. Alongside his freelance work within the arts sector, he is also frequently employed as a back office accountant, billing specialist, bank reconciliation expert, within the private and financial sector. He will be using this vast knowledge to manage the budget for Infectious. /The budget for Infectious will be tracked on a spreadsheet using formulas that automatically update the running balance as and when new data is keyed. For a project this size he will ring fence of 5% of the overall budget and will make it available only in the last few days prior to opening night for the show. In his experience it is this period where unexpected costs occur through technical and dress rehearsals./Currently we are waiting for our business to complete its registration with the banks and UK Companies House. For the time being, we are asking donations to be sent to the individual, Meghan Leslie McKay (Founder & Artistic Director of Welded Theatre)/Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: Innovative Theatre Company Needs You To Reach Funding Requirements. We Are So Close We Can Smell It! Thank You In Advance.

data.name: Me? A Caregiver?

info.description: Welcome to my Kickstarter page!There are 66 million caregivers for their parents in this country. That does not include parents with an ill or handicapped child or a spouse with Alzheimers or a sibling with cancer. Tragedy strikes and suddenly YOU are a caregiver.Caregiving for my disabled Mom was much harder than had I ever, EVER expected. I became fearless. I gained knowledge and experience. And what better way to share this with others than to write a memoir, Me? A Caregiver?My goal is to help others navigate their way through the rough waters of caregiving so that they can become fearless, ask questions, trust their instincts and find humor in almost any situation. Even changing an adult diaper. Really? Really. Then, my book received the Gold Medal Winner from the Living/Now Book Awards, and the Caregiver Friendly Award from Today’s Caregiver.  I stiil wanted to reach out to others. So I created a solo show that is informative, compassionate and with so much humor that caregivig will almost seem fun.HERE IS WHERE YOUR MONEY WILL GOStaging and directing. I brought on board the brilliant and talented Becca Wolff to help develop, stage and direct the show. Becca is a cross-media director, producer and dramaturg committed to developing new forms and attracting new audiences to the theater. She has her MFA from Yale School of Drama, Directing.Music. I hired the gifted singer/ songwriter Tom Faia to write and produce an upbeat, spirited but informative song about caregiving. I need musicians, vocalists and mixer.Production and promotion. And I need funds for an animator and/technician, publicity, promotion and a program.The show opens April 3rd at the Carl Cherry Center in Carmel, CA.And now I need your help!Kickstarter is a great tool for us struggling artists to make a/difference. But, to collect the money I must reach my goal. Otherwise, your money is refunded and I won't be able to make a difference in so many people's lives.I greatly appreciate your support on this project that is/so dear to my heart because caregviers and families need this .
info.risks and challenges: My passion for this project drives me. I am committed to it, heart and soul. This is all I do, all I dream of, it has become my life. I will not let it fail. I want to share my story with others, to give them hope, courage and help them find the humor. /The show opens at The Carl Cherry Center in Carmel, CA on April 3rd and run two weekends. Tickets will be availbale online through them. There will be a book signing after the show/Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: An edgy, hilarious, compassionate and honest show to help caregivers find courage, trust their instincts and above all, to laugh.

data.name: Not This Year ... I Have a Headache: a comedy about marriage

info.description: Testimonials from the future ..."I laughed so hard, I almost spit out a kidney.""I can't wait to go home, kiss my wife. She is wonderful. I'm a lucky man.""I am baffled and amazed that these guys somehow wrote a fun and fantastic play about marriage without once cursing."IN A NUTSHELL ...Steve Shaffer and Mark Schiff have pooled their comedic perspectives and written a play about love and tolerance, annoyance and acceptance, family and diplomacy, and commitment. Yes, it's about marriage. After three years of staged readings, rewrites, tinkering, testing, and perfecting - it's ready to open for a six-week "engagement" in a Los Angeles theater. This Kickstarter is to help fund that engagement.ABOUT THE PLAYNot This Year ... I Have a Headache examines the lives of two middle-aged married couples who are dealing with the modern struggles of an age-old institution. Through their trials, tribulations, and banter, the audience will (hopefully) laugh, cry (actually, not really cry - pretty much just laugh), and maybe even gain insight. Because this play, while a comedy, also reveals realistic pathways for confronting and navigating complex issues, many of which we can all identify with ... like religious differences, gay marriage, and divorce. Our characters use humor to learn plausible ways to renew love and enhance acceptance. This play is cheaper than therapy, and works better than Cialis.///This image from the first-ever reading of the play///ABOUT THIS CAMPAIGNSteve and Mark have been friends for decades, they have been stand-up performers and comedy writers for decades, and they have each been married for decades. Basically, everything they do, they do for decades. ///Left: Nancy and Mark Schiff; Right: Gretchen and Steve Shaffer///They are both big fans of the theater, and have long harbored dreams of producing a comedic play that would combine laughter and life lessons. They know and feel they understand the topic of marriage. They wrote Not This Year ... I Have a Headache as a true collaboration. They did test readings, private readings, table readings, and psychic readings. There has already been interest and kind words from many, including esteemed Theater Director and Choreographer Jonathan Cerullo, who sits on the selection committee for the prestigious Joseph A. Callaway Award. (see 1 minute video, below.)///////You'll need an HTML5 capable browser to see this content.//////Play////////////////////////////Replay with sound//////////Play with  sound/////////////00:00///00:00////////////////////////////////If this Kickstarter succeeds, Steve and Mark plan to first stage the play in Los Angeles. Where it goes from there is anybody's guess. THE "MARRIAGE" BETWEEN MARRIAGE & COMEDY///Great comic marriages  Stiller & Meara, Wilder & Radner, and (on-screen) Archie & Edith///"Marriage is a wonderful institution. But who wants to live in an institution?" - Groucho MarxThe origin of marriage is not precisely known, but it is known that the tradition of exchanging rings dates back to Ancient Egypt. The origin of comedy is believed to date back to the discovery of the wheel, when one caveman rolled his wheel over another caveman's foot. The longest marriage ever recorded was 91 years, 12 days, but hey - they got married young. When married couples laugh together (that's laugh together, not laugh at each other), they do tend to find greater contentment in life, and live longer. We're doing our part. ///Great modern marriages: Melinda & Bill Gates, Mary Matalin & James Carville, and Marge & Homer////"Laughter is the best medicine." - AnonymousComedy is one of very few things we have in this world that is addictive in a good way. It relieves stress, and improves disposition. It can also educate and heal. Good sarcasm can make one ponder ideas and viewpoints beyond their own. Marriage not only benefits from comedy, it practically requires it. And who better to write a comedy than comedians?Says Steve: Comedians are a fraternity. I have never looked back at my choice of career partly because I love that kinship with other comedians. Our friendships often last. There's mutual respect. It's good. Adds Mark: We're entertainers. We write and perform. Mostly, we write about what we know. We always need new material, so we accumulate "knowledge". This is why so many comedians win Nobel Prizes. ///Mark, w Larry Miller, Paul Reiser, and Jerry Seinfeld - like a scene from Diner//////LEFT: Steve w Jon Hayman and Dan Rosen at Hayman's Bar Mitzvah; RIGHT: Steve with Joe Bolster, Wayne Federman, Patty Rosborough, and Jim Mendrinos/// "Love is blind; marriage is the eye-opener." - Pauline Thomason////Classic marriages - Ozzie & Harriet, Lucy & Desi, Ozzy & Sharon///Stats prove that marriage is hard. You gotta want it. You gotta always remember why you chose this person for an eternity (or what seems like one). You gotta communicate. And ... you gotta laugh.  ///Historic marriages - JFK & Jackie, Rachel & Jackie Robinson, Ellen & Portia///MEET THE CHARACTERS////L to R: Rick Overton, Monica Piper, Avi Liberman, and Barb Heller. They did the table reads for us last month. How lucky we are to have friends like these!!!///Henry - Henry is the bighearted, hard-working, high school football coach, married to Cookie. He also teaches American history and while he has great respect for the subject, he'd rather be coaching. Sometimes he seems simple, but he's capable of sensitive insight.  New societal standards are clouding his moral judgment (shaped by a Catholic upbringing). His son is gay and getting married. Henry has the bumpiest road to travel. Although his path is uncertain, he keeps moving forward, one step at a time. You will recognize him as someone you know. Cookie – Cookie is a firecracker - tough, smart, funny, curious, and caustic. She’s a high school guidance counselor which works for her because she longs to be needed. She loves to stick her nose in anything, with a strong opinion that she won't hesitate to voice. She harbors a secret dream to someday be a relationship therapist.  She's married to Henry, loves him dearly, but is challenged by what she feels is his narrow-mindedness. She feels he’s gone from cute and quirky, to overweight and frustrating. But she wants the marriage to continue, because after all… love is love. Jake – Jake is a high school English teacher with a keen sense of humor, married to Aviva. He is erudite, cool, and bright but not a nerdy intellectual type. He is confident but never arrogant. He finds the simplicity and directness of his best friend, Henry, to be refreshing. He confides in Henry because he knows he’ll always get an honest answer. He’s a liberal Jew and a loyal friend, proud of Aviva and the religious sacrifice she made to be with him. He reads The New York Times for news, but also reads the New York Post because it has a better sports section. Aviva  - Aviva is a high school librarian, married to Jake. She is intelligent and academic, but also modest and easily embarrassed. She is delightfully quirky, loving, considerate person, often quiet and a simple voice of reason.  She can appear complicated. Aviva was raised in an orthodox Jewish home and felt she had to abandon many of her religious practices in order to marry Jake.  Resentments have been building up inside of her, and thanks to this play, she’ll have the opportunity to express them. MEET THE TEAMMARK SCHIFF///L to R: Mark w Paul Reiser; Mark w Jerry Seinfeld; Mark w a good book///Mark Schiff is a stand-up comedian, comedy writer, performer, and author. He recently toured with Jerry Seinfeld in Tel Aviv. He has had comedy specials on Showtime and HBO, and appeared on The Tonight Show and Late Night with David Letterman. His first play The Comic ran for 10 months in LA and was optioned by HBO for a film. He feels Not This Year, I Have a Headache is his finest work, and he's basically OK with carrying his old friend Shaffer along for the ride. ///L to R: Mark & wife at home; Mark & wife on bridge; Mark & wife in jail///STEVE SHAFFER///L to R: Steve w George Cariln; Steve w wife getting married; Steve w Jerry and Pete Barbuti///Steve Shaffer is a stand-up comedian, Ace Award-winning writer, and actor in film, TV, and commercials. He has toured with George Carlin, opened for The Beach Boys, and been a recurring character on Murphy Brown. He has appeared on The Tonight Show, Merv Griffin, Evening at the Improv, and Comedy Central. He has taught comedy at The New School. He feels Not This Year, I Have a Headache is his finest work, and he's basically OK with carrying his old friend Schiff along for the ride. ///L to R: Steve all smiles; Steve w Steve Hytner (Kenny Bania); Steve reacting to your pledge///HENRY SHAFFER///L to R: Henry in a pose; Henry the athlete; Henry in his natural state///Henry Shaffer attended Penn State, and studied film at The College of New Jersey. He currently freelances as an event photographer and videographer. He has strong video editing skills, as evidenced by this campaign's Project Video (above). TIMELINE, BUDGET, AND USE OF PROCEEDSTIMELINE: we believe the following estimated timeline to be reasonable: the Kickstarter concludes and settles in Mid-May; casting calls and rehearsals begin in June, continue through July. The play either launches in either August or October, 2016.BUDGET: we believe the pie chart below to be a reasonable estimation of what expenses are incurred and in what proportion. Upon success of Kickstarter, depending upon the degree of success, the budget will be fine-tuned. Overage monies will inure entirely to production, with perhaps a small amount toward marketing./////WHY KICKSTARTERSays Mark - "Like I said in the video, we came to Kickstarter for three reasons. (Four, including us needing the money.) First is Independence - we wrote this play from personal experience, and only if we are independent producers of the play can we be assured that the play will continue as an extension of those experiences. Second reason is Truth. We don't want to bow to pressure to avoid or tiptoe around topics, we want to present a truthful picture through believable characters, and convey that truth through comedy. In this way, while you laugh, maybe you learn. Finally, Collaboration. Writing with Steve has been a joyful collaboration. Producing this will be a larger collaboration. Marriage is always a collaboration. And we can't imagine a better place for such a collaborative venture than Kickstarter, where the power of collaboration is proven every day."NOTES ABOUT THE REWARDSORDERING MORE THAN TWO TICKETS: No problem. Pick the reward that applies to the ticket type you desire. Select it. Go to the next screen. On this screen, you can go to the top where it has a dollar amount, and change the dollar amount. Keep the same reward selection, just change the dollar amount to account for the number of tickets you would like. Then complete the transaction, and send us a message through Kickstarter of what you did by clicking CONTACT ME on the top right of the campaign page. Any questions, not to worry, we'll walk u through it. DELIVERY DATES: The delivery date of January 2017 reflects the outside date when the play will be performed, professionally captured, produced, and available. Many other Rewards will be fulfilled earlier, but since the play is a part of all rewards levels, we went with January 2017.CHOICES: All "choices" involved in any Reward tiers (t-shirt size, DVD or Blu- Ray, etc.) will be made after the campaign, on the Kickstarter survey form. / CUSTOM COMBOS:  If there are Rewards you'd like that are not available in quite the exact combo or quantity you prefer - send an email to the Project Creators by clicking "CONTACT ME" on the upper right; of course, we'll be glad to work it out.
info.risks and challenges: Steve and Mark are longtime writers and performers with substantial experience in production. They have done a great deal of preparation prior to launching this campaign, including locating several interested theaters. Both men are prepared to jump into the production of this play as their primary projects. Their wives are ecstatic with this as it will keep them out of the house more. Although the production of any play has a great many moving parts, this is mitigated here as this play benefits from a small cast, and limited sets and set changes. Steve and Mark can therefore say with absolute certainty that if the Kickstarter succeeds, the play will be performed, and the Rewards will be delivered as scheduled./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: Two long-time pals, comedy veterans, have written a hilarious new play. Neil Simon-ish w modern social mores. Let's help them stage it.

data.name: Itch + Scratch at Hackney Showroom

info.description: BEST NEW THEATRE. GREAT NIGHT OUT.Since July 2015 Itch + Scratch have been bringing the best new writing and theatrical talent to the masses. After three sell out events last year, we’re taking things up a gear. After taking some time to look at the current world of theatre, we're putting on the nights we'd like to go to ourselves. We want to create a platform where people can have enthralling discussions, share new work and, most importantly, have a Great Night Out. Our key aims are to.../Be a platform for emerging theatrical talent/Engage new audiences/Produce the best quality theatre and a great night out for all/Implement a 50/50 gender split and representation for BAME artists./We can't yet reveal the full line up for Itch + Scratch 4, but it will include party hats, a live podcast, live music from London talent, a house band, dancing, and lots of great short plays.We want to build a community not just for the theatre-makers, but for the theatre-watchers too."Itch and Scratch are scratching at something special. They are FINALLY bridging the gap and putting nights on for audiences, striving for a GOOD NIGHT OUT that people would actually like to go to and don’t have to go to" - Luke Barnes, Writer for Itch + Scratch #1 and #2 "Itch & Scratch offers an invaluable platform for emerging artists to try out new work. I would urge anyone with an idea at the back of their minds to write it and send it off. They're also lovely people and that makes it all a little sweeter."  - Rosie Kellett, Writer for Itch + Scratch #1 and #2To bring this night into fruition we need funds. £800 will cover the costs of.../A technician to light it all up beautifully/Marketing to spread the word and engage with new audiences/Rehearsal space so that we have a slick show for you all/Our set and decorations to make the dreams a reality/Any props so that the plays make sense/Resources for activities to make sure everyone can have the most fun
info.risks and challenges: We don't believe there to be any risks. We have already held three successful Itch + Scratch nights and have never made a loss. The date is booked in at the venue so it is definitely going ahead./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: After 3 successful nights last year, Itch+Scratch are back. New writing, live music and party fun. Best New Theatre, Great Night Out.

data.name: 3 Days In Savannah Part II

info.description: THE AMAZING TALENT///We are back at it again! There are so many wonderful young actors ready to present this work and getting chosen for the Summer New Work Series at Manhattan Repertory Theatre was such an honor we had to try this Kickstarter one more time. We broke our budget down to the bare minimum of what it will take to get this work put up here in Manhattan.  We have removed set pieces, changed certain elements of the show, and called in favors.  Your help in backing this new effort will get us up on the stage.  Our previous efforts were for both the Manhattan show and the Atlanta Show.  We decided to start where we are and if you back us today we can make it to the Manhattan StageHOW FAR WOULD YOU GO TO REVISIT THE PAST? In "3 Days In Savannah," we find out. The play has been selected to appear in the Summer  2014 New Works Series at Manhattan Repertory Theatre on 42nd Street in New York City! Manhattan Repertory Theatre is a forum for playwrights, directors, and actors to share their work.  I am so honored and excited that I can barely think.  As a young playwright this is such a wonderful surprise but our creative team needs your help to make it to 42nd street. The goal of this kickstarter is to fund the workshop presentation of the show in New York City at Manhattan Repertory and to ultimately bring a World Premiere of this work to Atlanta, Georgia.The story follows our two lead characters, Emme and Mason, as they navigate the secrets of their past.  There are some very talented people behind the play. We are raising funds to be able to provide for costumes, lighting, sound, rehearsal space, props, original music, dramaturgy services, programs, marketing materials, professional services, theatre deposits, and advertising for the show.  If we get fully funded we will be able to present a quality work of theatre on the Manhattan stage July 29-August 01. It would be an honor to present this work and to tell their story.  The original music of 3 Days is enchanting.  The play is full of humor and heartache.  We have an amazing cast that is ready to share this story with the audience. We are all teaching artists, working actors, small business owners, and friends who love to create! This is New York City, so production costs are astronomical. We want to create a quality presentation. The story is one that deals with issues of love, racism, colorism, betrayal, and heartbreak. We believe that it is a universal story
info.risks and challenges: Our major challenge is time. The show is set to open at the end of July and we need to utilize all the time we have to rehearse.  Rehearsal space in New York is very expensive. It can range from $30 per hour to $150.  This is New York City, so production costs are astronomical. We have to pay for professional services, and create major buzz in the form of marketing the show. We want to create a quality presentation. The story is one that deals with universal issues. We believe that it will be well received but in order to tell this story in a way that makes the most impact we need to use lights, sound cues, costumes, and props. All of which cost money. There are some brilliant minds behind the creation of this work. The playwright, Miranda Childers, enlisted the help of professional choreographers, dramaturgs, and costume designers to create the overall aesthetic of the play. In total over 20 people will be putting in many hours to make this project work. The major challenges also include securing the rights to music that is not original and securing standard contracts for professional services. Please consider supporting our process by backing this project./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: "3 Days In Savannah" explores the issues of love, racism, and regret while reminding us that, "life is a game and love is the prize."

data.name: Jestia and Raedon

info.description: Jestia - Sarah LivingstoneRaedon - Archie Henderson-ClelandDirected by Andrew BrockWritten by Lowell BelfieldProduced by Rachel Hunter and James HansenPublicity Design by Georgia HicksVideos by Hunter Allen/————————————————————Blurb/Jestia and Raedon are perfect for each other. Whatʼs more, they’ve been given a luxurious house to live in, three weeks to get to know one another, and the blazing adoration of millions of people around the world. But thereʼs only one catch: theyʼre about to enter the most difficult, world-renowned and life-changing gameshow ever created./Promises made. Pacts broken. Fear. Freedom. Romance. Love!/Previous praise:/'You know a show’s good when you never want it to end. Ever.’ ★★★★★ Three Weeks/————————————————————Our StoryThe Edinburgh Fringe is a notoriously difficult place to put on new plays as you're competing with (quite literally) thousands of other shows. Theatre, in particular, is a hard sell, especially since much of the festival now leans towards more traditional comedy such as stand up and sketch acts.We're a young theatre company fresh out of Cambridge, looking to work professionally in the roles we're taking on in this show. Funding is very difficult to access when you're starting out in theatre - which is why we've turned to kickstarter.However, as a group we're confident we can make this a great run at the Fringe. Together, we have experience of over 7 full fringe runs, and a combined portfolio of over 100 shows. We know how to work hard, how to advertise and how to get people in. Basically, we're totally willing to put in the time and the effort to get our show to reach as many people as possible. We can't wait to get started!The Team//////Lowell Belfield was Social  Secretary of the Cambridge Footlights 2011-12, where he wrote and performed in over ten comedy shows and plays. Since then he has taken his two-man musical comedy show ‘I am, I am’ to the Gilded Balloon, subsequently performing in the finals of the Musical Comedy Awards 2012, on the London comedy circuit and at the BBC comedy stages. His last show, the sketch show ‘PICK ME UP’, performed in London’s Hen and Chickens before going on to Just the Tonic, Edinburgh 2014, where it garnered rave reviews and won the Derek Award for Best Show. As social secretary of the Cambridge Footlights, he won the Cambridge Union’s Comedy Smoker with his debut comic performance in 2010. Since then he has written and performed in critically acclaimed sketch shows ‘Now, Now’, ‘PICK ME UP’, as well as two sell- out Footlights Spring Revues (‘The star man is Lowell Belfield’ - Varsity). In 2010 he performed alongside his friend and writing partner Harry Michell in the sold-out Footlights Harry Porter Prize nominated comic play ‘To Have And To Hold’ at St. Augustines, Edinburgh (***** -EdFringeReview), and in 2012 he debated the cast of ‘Made in Chelsea’ in the packed-out Cambridge Union, thoroughly winning the debate and defeating his Olly Locke-led opponents./////Andy Brock trained at E15 Acting School before attending Cambridge University where he performed with the Cambridge Footlights as well as appearing in the world famous Cambridge Greek Play. He also  performed in the 2012 Marlowe Society Showcase in London’s West End, directed by Max Stafford-Clark. As a director his focus is on new writing and devised work. He has directed Bereavement:The Musical, which performed at C Venues in Edinburgh 2012, which was nominated for Best New Musical in the 2012 Musical Theatre Matters Awards; the critically acclaimed devised play Babushka at C Venues in Edinburgh 2012, and most recently The Tales of the Ancholme Valley which he devised with his award winning theatre company, Troupe. /////Sarah Livingstone is an actor living in London. She has performed in an American Stage Tour of Shakespeare’s ‘Measure for Measure’, as part of CAST 2013, which returned to tour Britain receiving rave reviews and selling out both British and American legs of the tour. She has played the title roles in ‘[Lady] Hamlet’ at the ADC Theatre, as Alcestis in Ted Hughes’s ‘Alcestis’ at the ADC Theatre and as Electra in ‘The Complex: Oedipus + Electra’ by Mourkogiannis, Williams, and Lowenthal at The Space in Edinburgh 2012.As well as this she has performed in over fifteen plays including: ’The Other Line’ by Hellie Cranney & Ellen Robertson; ‘Blue Stockings’ by Jessica Swale, as Maeve Sullivan; in the ADC/Footlights Pantomime 2013:The Princess and the Pea by Ben Pope, Ryan Ammar and Hellie Cranney; in ‘The Deep Blue Sea’ by Terence Rattigan; ‘The Rose Tattoo’ by Tennessee Williams; and ‘The Seventh Seal’ by Ingmar Bergman (all at the ADC Theatre)./////Archie Henderson-Cleland is a member of Cambridge Footlights 2014-15, and has performed in and written numerous productions at the University. Recent theatre includes The Golden Fleece, by Ryan Ammar; Footlights Presents: Dumpf, which he also co-wrote; and STIFF!, by Sam Grabiner (all at the ADC theatre). Archie is also a stand-up comedian and has performed in numerous stand-up shows and smokers in Cambridge. Archie is a saxophonist and plays with Cambridge band Lorelai. /////Rachel Hunter produced the hugely successful comedy sketch show ‘PICK ME UP’, which performed a critically acclaimed run at Just the Tonic in Edinburgh 2013, eventually winning the Derek Award for Best Fringe Show. The show also did a tour of schools, Cambridge and London, all of which sold out. Rachel has been involved in seven shows at university and beyond, producing a sold out run of Jessica Swale’s ‘Blue Stockings’ at the ADC Theatre; ‘bash’ by Neil Labute, and new writing ‘Did You Say No Though’, both of which performed at Corpus Playroom. She is also an organiser of feminist events such as the ‘Women in Academia’ panel discussion she put together in January 2014./////James Hansen produced this year's sell-out Footlights Spring Revue, 'The History of Everything', which opened to universal critical acclaim at the ADC Theatre. He also produced 'Welcome Break' at the ADC, a new comic play by Footlight Alex MacKeith, which garnered rave reviews - 'immensely entertaining... truly intelligent comedy' (***** Cambridge Theatre Review), 'there aren't enough superlatives' (**** Cambridge Tab) and several sold out nights. Following Edinburgh, James will head to the USA, tour several English schools and then return to Cambridge with The Footlights International Tour Show 2014, 'Real Feelings', having stage-managed a sold-out run of the 2013 CUADC/Footlights Pantomime, 'The Princess & the Pea'. James has worked on 13 shows at university and beyond, including the critically acclaimed and sold-out 'Ivanov', 'Three Sisters', 'The Deep Blue Sea', and 'ENRON', (***** Varsity, Cambridge Tab, CTR) all at the ADC Theatre. He also produced music for Emmanuel May Ball in 2013.
info.risks and challenges: We've been to many fringes between us and are accustomed to the kinds of obstacles we're expected to face. We already have our slot at C Venues, our publicity designed and a publicity plan in place. As the main obstacle at the Fringe is getting our show noticed, and appealing to word of mouth, we've arranged London previews as a way of getting our show out and seen before the festival itself. /There is difficulty with finding technical teams when you're a new creative project, as the cost of this can often be high. Thanks to others from Cambridge University providing us with support and education in the technical aspects, we are working to make this area of the show run smoothly - as we have done many years before!/Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: Jestia and Raedon is a brand new romantic comedy play going to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival this summer.

data.name: Tissue by Louise Page. A play about Breast Cancer.

info.description: Tissue is a Play about breast cancer, it follows the journey of Sally as she goes through the ups and downs and the support she recieves from facing this terrifiying path that lays ahead of her.This will be an immersive piece of theatre with the audience genuinely feeling what Sally has to go through. using a mixture of multimedia, set pieces and surrealism. i hope to not only create an entertaining piece of theatre but also a complete understanding of what these women go through or in fact anyone that has to face the possibilty of dying or having to drastically change their life.My reasons for doing this are quite simple. i work as a nursing assistant as my "resting" Job, so i come in contact with situations like this all the time and see how it can affect not only the patient, but also the friends, familiy and even the staff.I have an ability to create theatre and the experiences of an acute medical ward, so why not marry the two and do something positive whilst entertaining as well.Utilising local facilities, some amazing professional actors and with a lot of support, this 8 performance one act play will be something special and thought provoking... leaving people with a better understanding of breast cancer so they will donate as much as they can towards the building of a new breast cancer unit in the city of Salisbury.
info.risks and challenges: One of the main risks are the use of multi media, as technology is always a gamble to rely on during a live performance, you never know what will happen (just look at Madonna!!!)/So i wont be relying on it as a device to further the narrative, but more a condiment to help the flavour of the scene./Rehearsals and venues is proving to be a difficulty, in getting everyone in the same room at the same time, providing a decent area to rehearse and keeping cost low. but with some research and explanation of the content of the play and why we are doing it, we're finding more and more people willing to help./I'm also on the look out for decent accommodation, again keeping costs low for the actors as some will need to stay a bit more frequently in the perfomance week. I'm hoping to be in talks with local B&B or hotels that are supporting the local hospital charity./The set design will be minimalist, with attention on different levels and lighting with a surrealistic looking hospital atmosphere. This will take a bit of time a money to create, but confident that our set designer will produce something exciting./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: "Tissue" is a play about Breast Cancer. Produced by MonkeyBond theatre co.ltd to raise awareness for Breast cancer.

data.name: Play A 'Role' In "Kickstarting A Battle Stage Plays Tour"

info.description: Battle Stage Plays is a production company based in Baltimore, MD that presents original stage play productions written by Playwright Ursula V. Battle. We currently present our stage plays at venues throughout the Baltimore/Metropolitan area.The goals of these dynamic stage play productions are to Uplift, Inspire, Educate, and Encourage. Attendees of all ages, nationalities, and walks of life, enjoy the timely material, hilarious slice-of-life comedy, riveting drama, life-changing spiritual messages, and inspirational singing. ///////////////In the wake of unemployment, drug addiction, peer pressure, and other societal ills, our productions also provide REAL SOLUTIONS. Our productions also highlight the importance of breast cancer awareness, and other health-related topics. Playwright Battle writes these original productions. /////Recently, she teamed up with Director extraordinaire (impresario) Dr. Gregory Wm. Branch, Executive Director and Founder of Unified Voices (UV) of Johns Hopkins. As a Battle Stage Plays Volunteer, Dr. Branch shares his talents and time to make our productions spectacular.  ///Dr. Gregory Wm. Branch, Director & Playwright Ursula V. Battle.///Our Team also includes dozens of performers and production members. We have been blessed to bring supporters our phenomenal stage play productions thanks to Dr. Branch and the rest of our Team's countless volunteer hours./////////////////////A few months ago, Baltimore City was cast in a negative light following the riots that took place after the death of Freddie Gray. But our productions illustrate that our young people are talented and doing positive things. ///////////////Our stage plays also showcase the talent of our seniors, and also provides them with an affordable, engaging form of entertainment.///Musician Jimmy Riley from our stage play production "DisChord in The Choir."/////////////The “good word of mouth” has spread about our stage plays. The outcome has been rave reviews, sold-out performances, media coverage, and a growing demand to bring our plays and their entertaining messages of hope in these trying times to other areas. //////////////////////All we need is a “Kickstart” to get this “Show On The Road.” That’s where YOU come in. We are seeking to raise funds to cover developmental costs and move closer towards touring our dynamic hit stage plays.. We are setting an initial funding goal of $5,000 to address our immediate needs.//////Our immediate needs include hiring a Promoter, purchasing costumes, set materials, conducting workshops and other activities. THE BEAUTY OF KICKERSTARTER & YOU is that we can raise funds beyond our $5,000 funding goal and begin aiming to reach "Stretch Goals". If we exceed our initial campaign goal, we can STRETCH to reach another monetary goal - $7,000, $10,000, $20,000, $50,000, $100,000...who knows?  The more we raise, the more we can do, and the closer we move towards making our tour dreams a reality. /////We could have the potential to raise enough money to enable us to approach and book major theatrical playhouses around the country, secure space rental for rehearsals, obtain music licenses, purchase props, cover travel expenses, and hire technical professionals. We could also purchase equipment such as musical instruments, microphones, and a storage facility to house it all.In August, 2014, we were blessed to work with renowned singer and actress D'Atra Hicks. ///D’Atra Hicks performing in "The Teachers' Lounge.".//////Ms. Hicks and other Cast Members during a performance of “The Teachers’ Lounge.”///Hicks' singing ability and rousing performance was dynamic. Building off that success, we would like to raise enough funds to retain at least one headliner performer for each of our stage play presentations.  //////We just need for you to give. It could be as little as $1 or as high as $10,000. Our current success has given us the necessary momentum to make this campaign “A HIT.” With that in mind, this campaign could also blossom into a major entrepreneurship venture, complete with a variety of job and internship opportunities for aspiring performers and production personnel. Which of our hit stage plays will be first to tour? Help us decide./////Will it be Ursula V. Battle's DisChord in The Choir? This gospel stage play musical comedy is about the dramatic chain of events, which follows the sudden death of The United in Victory Tabernacle on the Hill Freewill Baptist Catholic and Episcopal Church of God’s longtime musician and the ensuing scandal that rocks the church. This production played before sell-out audiences March 2015. /////Or, will it be Ursula V. Battle’s The Teachers’ Lounge? This production centers around the lives of six teachers who find refuge in The Teachers’ Lounge, where they gather during their /long-awaited lunch break to feast on juicy gossip, riveting secrets, insatiable desires, and even secret romance. This play has been presented on several occasions, and calls attention to the challenges educators face on a daily basis. ///PERFORMANCES: Sat. 12/19/15 (2 p.m. & 7 p.m.) and Sun. 12/20/15 (5 p.m.) at John Hopkins' Turner Auditorium, 720 N. Rutland Ave., Balt., MD 21205.///Or, will it be our soon-to-be-a-hit stage play Ursula V. Battle's My Big Phat Ghetto FABULE$$ Wedding?  Set to debut in Baltimore, Maryland at Johns Hopkins' Turner Auditorium December 19-20, 2015, this hilarious production is about what happens when a reversal of fortune causes a couple’s expensive Wedding plans to turn into a beer bucket budget nightmare, setting the stage for the most unforgettable Wedding you have ever attended. More on each of these stage plays and other productions can be found on www.battlestageplays.com/Maybe one day they all can tour.  Maybe one day we can bring one to your area. Maybe we could become the next national stage play touring sensation. But we have to start somewhere. That’s why we need YOU to PLAY A “SUPPORTING ROLE” in this production. //////////YOU can “PLAY A PART” in this campaign production story by BACKING THIS KICKSTARTER PROJECT.  HOW MUCH of a “SUPPORTING ROLE” you play in “Kickstarting A Battle Stage Plays National Tour” is up to you. Will you be a Thespian, Fan, Director, Celebrity, Star or Super Star?  No role is too big or too small. There are a variety of levels ranging from $1 to $10,000. The bigger the “SUPPORTING ROLE” you “PLAY”, the more prestigious your “PERFORMANCE AWARD” will be. If we reach, or even surpass our Campaign Goal, we can all SHOUT AND JUMP FOR JOY! Applause! Applause! data.name: Cortez

info.description: CORTEZ"I'd like to thank The Monterey Research Institute for generously funding my expedition to the Sea of Cortez. Things didn't go as planned." Milkwood Theater will be premiering their first stateside show, “Cortez” at FringeNYC 2014.Two marine biologists are at odds during the most important expedition of their career. When a stranded shark refuses to die, things get weird in this physical theatre piece about the nature of ego, love and revenge.Loosely Inspired by John Steinbeck’s real life recording of such a mission in “The Log of the Sea of Cortez,” Milkwood Theater uses the book’s philosophical musings to build an off-kilter physical theatre piece, equal parts absurd humor and inventive storytelling. The young company was moved by mankind's enthusiasm and expertise on the animal kingdom but naivete about own history and patterns. A rented sardine boat on a scientific expedition became an ideal setting to get to the heart of what separates and connects us to the animal and plant worlds we study.    Cast: Cory Lawson, Heather Holmes, Peter Waluk and David RileyWriter: Judith GoudsmitDirector: David RileySet design: Mar UrrestarazuProjection Design: Matthew KeffProducer/PR and marketing: Laura Henny
info.risks and challenges: The biggest challenge we face is trying to self produce a new show in New York, where the competition for funds, publicity and space is fierce. We've solved much of that simply by being chosen by The NYC Fringe festival, but we still need help raising the money needed for the production. We know our brand of theatre is unique and has a place in New York's theatre scene. We are eager to introduce everyone to Milkwood's style!/Learn about accountability on Kickstarter
