data.name: From Providence to Cuba: A Historic Theater Adventure

info.description: Rhode Island's very own ECAS Theater is traveling to Cuba in early July to perform in a theater festival in Cuba. ECAS has been bringing Latino-themed and Spanish-language performing arts to Rhode Island since 1997. The performances in Cuba, scheduled for July 2, 3 and 4, will complete a circuit that began in 2013, when a playwright living in Cuba, Jesus Del Castillo, entered a new play, Deporte Nacional, into a writing contest sponsored by the Providence Community Libraries (PCL) and several Rhode Island-based Latino arts organizations. ECAS staged the play in Providence last year and Del Castillo traveled to Providence to watch its premiere. Now ECAS has been invited to present it in Cuba. Deporte Nacional is a semi-biographical play about a man, Orestes, who has turned his back on baseball, Cuba’s national sport, in an effort to erase painful memories involving his mother’s murder and his father’s exile in the US. An unexpected visitor challenges his view of the game and the world, changing Orestes’ life forever. The play explores the Cuban exile experience from the perspective of those left behind, and also touches on issues of acceptance and diversity related to sexual identity in contemporary Cuban society./This will be the play's premiere in Cuba and the ECAS cast is also going to participate in community workshops in Havana and Matanzas. Upon their return, the cast will host a community forum to talk about their experiences in Cuba and begin a conversation about building cultural bridges between both countries. The Cuban Ministry of Culture has extended an invitation to the theater group to present the play in a theater festival that takes place in July. That invitation, however, does not include coverage of travel or accommodations for ECAS Theater. That's up to us (with your generous support)./The play has a cast of five actors. ECAS needs to raise $7,000 to cover travel expenses. We are already on our way to that goal. You can help make this possible. Background on the play: http://oncubamagazine.com/culture/deporte-nacional-will-premiere-in-the-united-states/
info.risks and challenges: The risks and obstacles involved in completing this project involve funding, as it is very expensive to get to Cuba. We are a grassroots, all-volunteer arts organization with very limited resources. We are raising funds through performances, personal donations, and now through Kickstarter. We are within reach of our goal and need your generous support! All funds being raised will go exclusively to covering travel and accomodations for our five actors./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: Providence's Latino theater, ECAS Theater, is headed to Cuba in July to premiere an original Cuban play there. Help us make history!

data.name: The Saltbox Theatre Collective Seed Money Project

info.description: The Saltbox Theatre Collective is a brand new not-for-profit theatre company in Illinois founded by Brian Fruits. /What is this all about, may I ask?Officially incorporated on December 4, 2014, the company is seeking "seed money" in order to:/Rent proper theatre space/Buy script royalties /Pay for proper publicity/We are hoping to open the season with Eurpides's The Bacchae (translated by Chicago's own Nicolas Rudall) on September 3rd. The show will be performed 12 times at the at Madison Street Theatre in Oak Park, Illinois (just outside Chicago). Why Kickstarter?We are aiming to provide the reward options to you as a way to say, "Thank You" for your support and interest in our theatre collective.  Kickstarter allows us to raise "seed money" for we are just starting out and need to gain financial backing as our 501(c)(3) processes. A donation in order to raise a small amount of money would be very helpful at this time. We will send you a "thank you" letter with our E.I.N on it for tax purposes along with your reward(s).We feel that we can reach a wide variety of people through Kickstarter!Kickstarter, ultimately, aims to give each one of us a chance to fund our ideas, starting directly with the people who are closest to it (friends, fans, community-fellows). And it’s a way to break beyond the traditional methods — loans, investment, industry deals, grants — to discover that we can offer each other value through creation without a middleman dictating the product and terms.How much money is needed from me?We are seeking the amount of $3,871.00 to get us off the ground. Currently, our 501(c)(3) status is under review, pending and processing! What are you all about? I want to know a little more! I am very curious!!/The Saltbox Theatre Collective's mission is to share stories that realize the human experience. We hope to one day have our own space in Chicago and produce productions that involve educators, novice performers and designers, and other artists who would not normally be involved in the theatrical process. What else do you foresee going on with Saltbox in future?We also hope to one day produce shows with students and adults whom have special needs and disabilities for we feel there is a great need for this in the Chicago land area. Also, we hope to one day provide mini-theatre festivals partnering with other small, not-for-profit theatre companies in order to create partnerships. Any and all additional "seed money" will go towards future productions, rental space and artist funding. Who are you? I would love to see the people involved in this project!I encourage you to watch the four minute video above and browse our website at www.saltboxtheatre.org to get a sense of what we are about.Though we are discovering our voice and "Identity" this season, there are many people who have not been paid and have volunteered so much of their time already in support of our efforts. These wonderful people are (in no specific order): /Jeramie Simmons /David and Jill Burke /Katie Zisson /Amy Moore /Lauren Demerath /Andrea and Molly Gustafson /David Rice /Don Kovach /Andy Pederson /Chris Onken /Steven Cox /Ben Schneider /Morgan Brown /Mario Treto, Jr. /Mark and Terri Bernstien /Danielle Swanson /Chas Howard /Lisa Weber /Rosemary Foley/April Hunsucker/Jared Williams /Stephen Hancock /Alice Berry /John Yorke /Marie & Ira Goodkin /Corwyn Cullum /Daniel and Michael Appearson/What is your closing statement?If you support live theatre, the arts, me (Brian) or any of the above mentioned people, we ask you to kindly consider making a small or large donation in their honor. To me, they are family, and will never be forgotten as we begin building our foundation. We invite you to be a part of us as we continue to "lay down the bricks."The above video was made by: Bradley LaRocco www.missingbuttonentertainment.com -bradley@missingbuttonentertainment.comChuck Lewis www.offandennui.com - chuck@offandennui.comThese two men are wonderful and great to work with should you need anyone for special video projects. Also, a very special "thank you" goes out to Amy Moore who does all our graphic designs and helped with the creation of this here Kickstarter. Her e-mail is amy.moore.design@gmail.com should you need to hire someone who designed our logo and does so much more!
info.risks and challenges: One of the many obstacles moving forward (once we gain funding) will be finding new ways to gain audience members in an already theatre-saturated town. Chicago is big though and full of opportunities. We do not foresee issues keeping unique and new audiences members once we start our season through this "seed money" fundraiser. We feel very confident and believe in the project 100%./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: The Saltbox Theatre Collective is a brand new not-for-profit theatre company in Illinois.

data.name: Unhinged Creations Presents 'Phantom Pain' - Ed Fringe 2014

info.description: We are Unhinged Creations, a fledgling theatre company founded at the University of Warwick. This year we're taking our first play, Phantom Pain, to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival. Phantom Pain is a new play written by John Servante - the play promotes mental health awareness and is produced, directed and performed by members of the company.  During his time at university, John suffered with mental health issues – chronic depression and severe anxiety. As a result of the stigma that surrounds this John set out, through Unhinged Creations, to create artistic responses to mental illness. We hope these will be socially responsible pieces which help to raise awareness about mental health issues and in the long term the company hopes to afford creative opportunities to individuals suffering with mental illness. Phantom Pain follows the lives of a group of people as they come to terms with the suicide of one of their friends, James, and explores the various responses people have to suicide, seeking to dispel some of the notions people hold about mental illness. Having already had a successful run at the University of Warwick (leading to the National Student Drama Festival to positively review it as a “strange, touching, poignant piece of theatre”), it is to be performed at Theatre 2, The Space@Northbridge, between 11th and 16th August. After each performance, collections will be held in the lobby for the mental health charity Mind, as the play is in aid of the charity. /Unfortunately, as the play seeks to raise awareness about mental health issues, which include suicide, certain avenues are closed to us for fundraising (especially funding through any religious groups). //The controversial nature of the text also makes public sponsorship problematic, as people are uncomfortable with supporting artistic responses to suicide and suicidal thoughts. This is somewhat distressing: one in four people each year will suffer with a mental health issue and the leading cause of death in males of our age group is suicide. In short, this taboo subject desperately needs to be talked about!
info.risks and challenges: Financial concern for the production as well as the cast and crew is our major challenge. However, we obviously also face the challenges of securing an audience once we're up in Edinburgh as well as managing to raise money for Mind./We plan to aggressively market our show in Edinburgh. We hope the piece will speak for itself and leave audiences with much to discuss as they leave the theatre, but getting people to come and see a show which tackles our subject matter is very difficult. Our plan is to showcase select scenes which would be appropriate and respectful. We also hope, through social media and flyering, to give insight in to what it's like to work on a project about mental illness and to spread our enthusiasm for the issues the play seeks to discuss./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: Phantom Pain - a new play promoting mental health awareness written and performed by fledgling theatre company Unhinged Creations.

data.name: WILDE TALES

info.description: WHO ARE WE?Hello! We’re Suitcase Civilians, and we’re presenting Wilde Tales, a theatrical adaptation of Oscar Wilde’s short stories. The show will play at The Space in London from April 5-10, 2016. It’s written and directed by Sepy Baghaei, and performed by Jade Allen, Harriett Attwood, Heath Ivey-Law, and Ashley Pekri.WHAT DO WE NEED?As this is an independent production, we need a little bit of help covering our costs! Below is a breakdown of what we need, and an estimate of how much it will cost:/Rehearsal Space Hire (£100) /Props/Consumables (£100) /Costume (£50) /Equipment hire (£60) /Postcard printing and social media advertising (£50)/TOTAL = £360We’re setting our goal at £250 – if we make it beyond that, great! If not, the initial target would be fantastic too.Thanks so much for your help, and we look forward to seeing you at the show!
info.risks and challenges: With any independent production, the biggest challenge is getting the word out there, and getting bums on seats! Being able to afford marketing materials such as postcards and social media advertising is a big help in doing this./Furthermore, making your own work means you can sometimes be limited in making the best possible show, simply due to finances. While we aren’t looking to build a huge elaborate set or have actors flying from the ceiling, we would like to be able to afford basic costume, props and lighting elements to create a show where big ambitions aren’t stifled due to lack of resources./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: A theatrical adaptation of Oscar Wilde's short stories, presented by Suitcase Civilians at The Space, April 5-10 2016.

data.name: Das Ding - A Globetrotting Comedy

info.description: Das Ding will be performed at the New Diorama Theatre in London, UK from 14 October - 1 November 2014 in a production directed by Tanja Pagnuco.  http://newdiorama.com/whats-on/das-dingThe PlayThe play follows the journey of a cotton boll that travels around the world: from the fields in Africa to being made into a t-shirt in China to being sold in Europe and being then recycled and shipped back to Africa. Throughout this journey, we encounter different characters such as a married couple in Germany, a touring photographer, two Chinese entrepreneurs, a Swiss development aid worker and an African farmer. They are all delicately linked by threads so slight they are initially invisible, but as the play unfolds, we start seeing a globe-spanning network of interdependencies. The thing (the cotton ball) looks on amazed at the wheelings and dealings of humanity. Das Ding offers a moving and humorous observation on our globalised world. BudgetWe are very grateful to have received a Small Grants Fund from the Arts Council of England, the support from the Swiss Cultural Fund towards our Swiss set and costume designer and the support of the Unity Theatre Trust. This has meant that we've been able to secure the rights for the play, our venue, the salaries for our cast and creatives and fund part of our ambitious set design. A theatre production at a professional level requires unfortunately more budget to pay other aspects of a production such as rehearsal space, marketing and the costumes of these 14 characters. By raising this money, it means we will not only get this project on its feet, but the project will be of the highest quality possible by having the space to form and for set/costume designer Martina Trottmann and director Tanja Pagnuco to fully realise their vision for Das Ding./This ProductionDas Ding is a black comedy about our globalised world. It has a lot of humour in the depiction of its characters and the situations they find themselves involved in but underneath all that lies a lot of tension, fear and insecurities about the future of our globalised world, which this production is aiming to explore.  /In rehearsals, we are joining a text-based approach to a more European theatre approach that incorporates devising into play-text, improvisation and techniques to trigger the actors’ playfulness, deconstructing the narrative to create images and moods. Although the play talks about us today and is incredibly true to the mechanisms of our world, the style of the play demands non-naturalism, a heightened form of acting and a strong sense of playfulness./The Cast This piece will be performed by a cast of 5 who will play 14 characters. ///Martins Imhangbe, Ivy Corbin, Dylan Kennedy, Leo Wan and Christopher Lane/// The Creative teamDirector: Tanja Pagnuco/Set and Costume Designer: Martina Trottmann/Lighting Designer: Pablo Fernandez-Baz/Sound Designer: Max Pappenheim/Assistant Director: Katharina Reinthaller/The Playwright////Philipp Löhle - Playwright///Philipp Löhle is/an Award-winning German playwright. His plays have been performed on main/stages throughout Europe. In 2007, he won a commission from the Stückemarkt of/the Berliner Theatertreffen. His play Call Me Gospodin was nominated for the Mülheimer/Dramatikerpreis in 2008. In 2012, he was nominated for the Mülheimer/Dramatikerpreis and won the audience award for Das Ding. /The Co-Producers: StoneCrabs Theatre CompanyStoneCrabs is a professional theatre company based in Lewisham, South London with an artistic policy to deliver British and international Theatre and Educational and arts projects at the highest professional standards. Drawing upon the creativity of artists and writers of many cultures, StoneCrabs seeks to create a deeper understanding of the richness and diversity of the society in which we live.///StoneCrabs Theatre Company - Co-Producers
info.risks and challenges: This production is full of challenges and that’s probably why it feels so exciting. /First of all, putting on any European new writing play on the London Fringe is never an easy task. You have to convince the funders, the venue and then the audiences that although they might not yet have heard about this playwright, nor this play, they need to trust you that it is an excellent play and that this playwright should be on our UK stages, and especially in a global city like London. /Then, there are the challenges within the play itself: 14 characters including one thing with a voice, more than 5 narratives all intertwined taking place in 9 different countries, scenes that jump back and forth in time, some scenes addressed to the audience, others behind a fourth wall... and all of this played out by just 5 actors!/Finally, another challenge has been more self-made: we have an ambitious vision for the piece in terms of the set design. Without revealing too much, our production will be full of things (‘das ding’ in German means ‘the thing’) and quite a few kilos of cotton!/Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: StoneCrabs is thrilled to bring to the UK the first English production of Philipp Löhle’s play Das Ding (The Thing).

data.name: FRESH PRODUCE'd LA presents: Friends in Transient Places

info.description: We THANK YOU for supporting new work. #kickstartfreshFRIENDS IN TRANSIENT PLACES by Jonathan Caren tells the story of a group of strangers flying from New York to Los Angeles. From baggage claim at JFK, to soaring through an electrical storm in the sky, and ending at LAX, the characters focus on their own troubles - hoarding, autism, estranged fathers, past lives, fallen religiosity, ex-boyfriends, new girlfriends, dead dogs... Whatever it is, it consumes them. As they travel from one side of the country to the other, we learn that their human connections are deeper than they'll ever realize. What makes this play special? To be honest, FRIENDS is awesome. Really. It's a unique play that combines musical theater elements, magical realism, a large cast of diverse characters, and still yanks at the heart strings. It reflects on the heart, life, and missed opportunities. This is a story for today - when we fear that hate will overtake love, while we question our neighbors' humanity, and when we yearn for entertainment with meaning.Who is FRESH PRODUCE'd? We are a group of theatre artists who serve emerging writers. We strive to bring new, alternative style theater to life. www.getfreshproduced.comWhat does FRESH PRODUCE'd do? Four times a year, we workshop new pieces. Twice a year we bring full-length productions to LA audiences. Our workshops are by donation only and we make no money from them in order to ensure that everybody in the LA arts community has the opportunity to see new works while connecting with a community of artists.Our full-length productions are self-funded. As FRIENDS IN TRANSIENT PLACES is such a large-scale production, we need to supplement our regular budget.What the money will go to:$1350 - Theater rental.$4200 - Designers, director, stage manager, musicians, playwright, and actor fees. We believe that it is of the utmost importance to pay professional artists respectable rates in order to grow the theater community.$1050 - Set, props and costumes.$600 - Designing and printing programs, postcards, posters. Printing scripts. Online notices.$300 - Insurance.$500 - Rehearsal space.Total fundraising needs: $8,000
info.risks and challenges: This campaign will allow us the opportunity to continue the work we do and to expand and diversify. But theater is risky - and we know this because it isn't our first production. So when problems arise, we will problem solve our way out of them, just as we've done in the past for our previous 3 successful productions. The show must go on! /And guess what? This should be the last time we'll have to fundraise in this manner - because we are applying to be a 501c3! We're not there yet, so right now we need your help./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: FPLA presents FRIENDS IN TRANSIENT PLACES by Jonathan Caren: a magical story of modern life.

data.name: Today I Live

info.description: ABOUT THIS PROJECT'Today I Live' is a new play by British/American playwright Susan-Jane Harrison. This production is brought to you as part of the RADA Festival (Royal Academy of Dramatic Art) in London. It plays at the GBS Theatre RADA between 23 June and 2 July 2016./Can desire transcend time?/ /A man and a woman living centuries apart in the same flat gradually become aware of one another. This mysterious sexual charge permeates their work and their sleep, driving them to distraction and inspiration./ /In 2017, Niaz, a British-Iranian artist seeks refuge to unravel which elements of her current crisis are existential and which are marital. In 1821, Michael, an Irish mapmaker, is scarred by the Napoleonic wars, his new solitary life a temporary shield from the shadows of his Dublin past./ /As the walls between Michael and Niaz crumble, ghosts long-forgotten find their way home. / /"Today I Live" explores the trauma of immigration, drawing on Ferdowsi's epic poem "Shahnameh" and legends of the Irish hero Cúchulainn. /What makes it stand out?/ /‘Today I Live’, written by RADA graduate by Susan-Jane Harrison is a rich and subtle story, extensively work-shopped and meticulously researched. We have assembled an outstanding company:/ /Directed by Delyth Jones (Artistic Director Io Theatre Company)/Designed by Amanda Mascarenhas/Cast: Richard Cotton, Viss Elliot Safavi, Loz Keystone, Rob Marni and Soudabeh Neeya /‘Today I Live’ is a ghost story. Effectively, we see two stories play out simultaneously in the same flat, stories that weave between one another. Through the course of the play, characters gradually become aware of the presence of others through shared objects, sounds and smells. Desire for persons unknown and unseen begins to grow. The link between Persian and Irish legends, in which the play is steeped, becomes a visceral connection between characters separated by almost 200 years. It is also a play about immigration, what it means to be disconnected from one’s place of origin and how that sense of disconnection permeates all aspects of life - an issue so pressing in our world today.What's the plan?//The venue for this current production is the GBS Theatre RADA in central London and the play is bought to you as part of the RADA Festival 2016. The producers are Local Dystopia (USA) and Fab Shack Productions (UK). Our determination is for this production to spark further interest and generate a future life for the play./Where does the money go?/ /We have just over £5,000 cash and over £20,000 worth of in-kind support (venue, technical provision, graphic designer, printing). So we just have enough money to stage the play and the production is going ahead. The cash that we have is going towards to the wages of the actors and creative team, but we are asking for your help to raise a further £3350 to lift wages to the equivalent of the minimum set out by the actors’ union Equity and take the set design and construction to the level that the production requires./THE TEAM/Susan-Jane Harrison – Playwright/Susan-Jane Harrison is a British-American playwright and performer.  She trained as an actor at RADA, with a Masters of Fine Arts from the University of California at Davis.  As performer and playwright, Harrison continues to be produced in both the UK and USA.  Most notably she has worked with BBC Radio, and A&BC Theatre Co.  In the USA, with Berkeley Repertory Theatre, Aurora Theatre Company, Woman's Will, ACT, California Shakespeare Company and A Traveling Jewish Theater.   She was last seen performing in her solo show Possession on Theatre Row in NYC at United Solo Festival.  This summer she will be originating the role of Love in a world premiere of her play “Hunting Love” in San Francisco.//Delyth Jones – Director/Delyth is Artistic Director of Io Theatre Company for whom she has co-created and directed eight productions regionally and nationally, including A Christmas Carol, A Well Remembered Voice, Dickens' Ghosts and The Snow Spider.  She is currently preparing for Io Theatre Company's newest production, The Confessions of Fanny Cradock. Delyth has also built a varied career as a freelance theatre director. She has made three pieces of work about science; Dark Matters with Andrew Pontzen and Tom Whyntie, Brainsex with Timandra Harkness, and most recently Caution: Safety Goggles Required with Greg Foot which is currently touring nationally. In addition to directing Delyth works as a director and writer of comedy, a dramaturg, a deviser of new work and a workshop leader./	/Richard Cotton – Producer/playing Michael /Richard trained at RADA and has worked extensively in theatre, including work at the RNT, RSC, Regents Park Open Air Theatre, Manchester Library, English Touring Theatre, Oxford Stage Co., The Wrestling School and in the West End. Television and film work includes The Office, Foyles War, The Libertine and Love Actually. Richard is also a prolific voice artist and songwriter./Viss Elliot Safavi – playing NiazViss trained at RADA. Her theatre credits include: 'Othello'- RSC, 'Invasion!' Soho Theatre, 'Smother'- Artangel, 'Crocodile Seeking Refuge'- Lyric Hammersmith, 'Gorgeous' (one woman show)- British Council International Tour and 'Bitchkiss'- BAC. Viss played the female lead in the award winning foreign feature film 'Baba Joon', her other Film and TV credits include: 'Happy-Go-Lucky'- Mike Leigh, 'Fugee Girl'- Channel 4 and a medley of BBC favourites- Eastenders, Holby City and Doctors. Viss is thrilled to be reunited with the GBS theatre for the run of 'Today I Live'.Loz Keystone – playing Padraic Theatre credits include: Asking Rembrandt (The Old Red Lion), Little Pieces of Gold (Southwark Playhouse), the world premier of Joe Orton's Fred & Madge (The Hope Theatre) and Dying in the Street (The Wrestling School / The Print Room)//Film credits: Night Bus (Winner: Best Feature Film - British Independent Film Festival & BFI London Film Festival Official Selection), Schadenfreude (due for release 2016)//Loz is currently writing and starring in Better Now, a TV comedy-drama produced by Compulsory. http://www.compulsoryviewing.co.uk//Rob Marni – playing Farhad/Rob trained at The Bristol Old Vic Theatre School. He has worked in various Film and TV titles including Stephen Poliakoffs The Tribe, Spooks 6.1,Kavanagh QC and soon to be released Sit and Watch at The Hamburg Film Festival, Rob has just completed filming his first short film Velvet Thompson as Actor and Director. His Theatre Credits Include The Marriage of Figero Crucible Theatre Sheffield, Romeo and	 Juliet Coventry Belgrade,The Rape of Tamarthe Lyric Studio London./Soudabeh Neeya/ – playing Mina/Leads: Crucible, The Possessed, Medea, Prometheus in Evin, Rostam & Esfandiar, Return, Sun Caged, A Woman Alone, Invitation, Depiction of Stoning, Debris of love, Death & Maiden, No Exit in Persian, and a few productions also as director.//Other work includes: The Train Years, Struck By Lightning, Four Play, In Broad Daylight, I Miss My War, Women of Troy, Bear & Proposal, Swann Song, Happy Days in English as well as a number of national/international tours and festivals.//Radio: acted and directed (stage & BBC4). //Feature, short films: Not Without My Daughter, Gholam 2014; Still Waters, AVA 2013, Five 2015//TV: The Prince, The Bill, Dangerfield, Kavana QC, New Worlds 2014  /Dubbing: BBC-Persian
info.risks and challenges: There are no risks to speak of. The production is going ahead. The creative team is extremely experienced. The RADA Festival itself has been running for four years with great success./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: A London flat, two stories play simultaneously. Irish mapmaker 1821, Iranian artist present day. Each senses the other. Worlds collide.

data.name: Uprising Theatre Company's First Production

info.description: We believe in the power of stories to change the world. By telling stories we help people think differently about issues and give them an emotional connection which inspires them to action. By telling powerful stories we will inspire people to make lasting changes in their lives and to invest in making meaningful change in their community. By partnering with local organizations we give people immediate contact with those doing work on the ground that they can get involved with while their emotions are still engaged.Our first show is one that was voted on by our Facebook community! It's called "Cup of Salvation". A young priest takes a job bartending to make ends meet. This creates conflict both with his Bishop and church, but also in his own conscience as he realizes that the conversations he's having at the bar are more meaningful than many of the conversations he's having in his ministry. We're working on partnering with local new church starts that are doing things in innovative ways, as well as new local breweries who are giving back to the communities.  The money we raise will go toward renting theatre space (about $4000), sets, marketing, and paying some of the people involved, as well as printing and shipping all of the perks. $6000 is the bare minimum to make this show happen. Anything we raise over the $6000 will allow us to pay more of the people involved and do more in-depth marketing.
info.risks and challenges: Obviously any theatre project could face delays; availability of space, actors, etc. But we don't forsee any major issues./I've written and produced two full length plays before and have connections to a lot of local non-profits. We also have leads on potential theatre space./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: We believe in the power of stories to change the world. Theatre that inspires transformation.

data.name: The Girl Who Touched the Stars

info.description: 'The Girl Who Touched the Stars'Two sisters make a set of paper dolls which take them on a journey across lands, where the paper dolls are real people. We discover that nothing and no-one is every really gone as long as you have your memories..///There Once Was a Princess Called Felicity///This project began with an experimental performance at Bishop Grosseteste University, After great success, we decided to create a small organisation which we names: Cardboard Castles. In order to give us a way to perform children's theatre to the local community. After getting the basics done and out of the way decided our first task would be to extend this project and give it a real purpose. ///Paper Dolls Ft The Friendly but Grumpy Crocodile///The performance and the workshop which we wish to do, is aimed at 6-11 year old's and focuses on bereavement and terminal illness, the different ways people deal with these things, and the ways we should approach the issues with young people. It deals with the difficult topic in a child friendly manner, but not in a way which patronises young people. We believe that this is a topic which is very important to educate both adults and young people on. It takes a very long time for anyone to process the illness or the loss of a family member, and it can take even longer if handled wrong. We are hoping to take this performance and an accompanying workshop into local primary schools in and around Lincoln around May/June time of 2016 and then up to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival this August.Something a little bit quirky about our project is that everything we do takes place in a large tent, which the audience are seated in with the performance happening in the middle and around the tent. Comments we have received about this suggest that the use of the tent creates a small escape for a short period of time for our audience, it allows adults to get back in touch with their younger side and really experience the events of the piece with the two sisters, from a child's perspective.///Where the Magic Happens///There are currently ten people involved in this project, including the original cast/crew (Ella Manning, Kara Bailey, Maria Sands and Zachary Anthony-Ciarla, Daniel Swift, and myself- Shannon Toyne) and some new people who have come on board after seeing our initial performances (Joe Brammer, Hannah Smith, India Swordy, Emily Spalding) Every person involved is extremely dedicated to getting it on it's feet and making this happen. ///Cast Photo at Our Initial Performance- 2015///The Money Bit Unfortunately project's like these don't happen for nothing! Although currently we are not taking a wage from this project, as we want to use it as a start up so we can offer more projects like these to the community. The cost of this project is currently estimated around £5,500 this includes, all of our costs up until we are in Edinburgh, this money would allow us to bring our performance into many schools in and around Lincoln, and have an impact on many groups of young people. Before giving us an additional opportunity to take it up to Edinburgh and make some new contacts and friends in the arts industry, which will hopefully give us all the tools we need to start building ourselves up as an organisation! The reason we have put our target at around £700 is because whilst this is happening, we are also working hard ourselves to raise additional funds all of which we will keep you up to date on! So far we have baked hundreds of cakes, and ran a fairly crazy theatre themed pub quiz, all of these are small events, which add up in time, and we won't stop running these until we have the funds we need.However these events can only take us so far, so we are turning to you guys in hopes you will see the importance of our project, and the dedication we are putting in to get it off the ground! No donation is too small, and we gratefully appreciate any help we receive over this period. Thank-you for reading our story, and don't hesitate to ask us any questions in our question box! ///I Love Your Hat, Can We Swap?
info.risks and challenges: Well for a start, the putting up of the tent is an interesting and challenging process! /But on a serious note, this is just the tip of the iceberg for the financial side of this project, as I stated above, this project needs around £5500 to run, however regardless of how this goes, we will still be going ahead with the project, it does however mean we might have to make some sacrifices, which we believe alter the impact our performance has, the tent would probably be one of the first things we have to cut back on, which is sad as it is the thing which draws people in, and what really involves the entire audience with our performance. /We will however, be doing everything in our power regardless of the success of this kickstarter, to do this project justice and make it happen! /So thanks in advance for any support you have to offer us!/Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: Two sisters make a set of paper dolls which take them on a journey across lands, creating memories along the way.

data.name: The Other Group Theatre

info.description: When you're shooting for the stars you need a little help building the ship! With the raised funds by you generous believers in our mission, all proceeds would go to paying for performance space, cast, crew, play rights, advertising and thanking EVERYONE involved! If the company is a success (which it will be) then we will expand and put on shows for charity and children! The -Other- Group Theatre is all about giving back to the community and inspiring others through great plays and crafted actors!The -Other- Group Theatre might just be starting out but we plan to make a crater-sized impact in the theater scene!
info.risks and challenges: A big question when something takes off is "How can I make this last?" Since The -Other- Group Theatre is a growing company, we are making sure we are not missing a single step to make this company flourish. I personally make sure all cast, crew, performance space and the play rights are all taken care of before we make the bigger, more financial moves. /Challenges are always faced with new businesses but I never backed down from a challenge in my life. I always see it through till the end, no matter the outcome and I make it a top priority to let everyone involved know the status of the company. This is a company I am more than passionate about and I will do whatever it takes to keep it living and making a positive difference in the entertainment world./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.name: Ultramarine Girl: A Cup Full of Courage

info.description: Ultramarine Girl: A Cup Full of Courage is a new, original play that focuses/on spina bifida awareness. Local playwright Aspen Mock and community activist/Rachel Allen are collaborating on a project that will serve as a fundraiser and/promote spina bifida awareness. After copious research and working with/consultant Riley Allen (who is an expert in living with spina bifida), Aspen/Mock has written an original, fictional play entitled Ultramarine Girl: A Cup/Full of Courage, which will have its world premiere July 2015 at Greater/Johnstown Career and Technology Center in Johnstown, Pennsylvania./About the Show:/This one act play is a contemporary fantasy that takes place in a quaint/cottage nestled in a picturesque beach on the Maryland shoreline. Orva, the/main character, is a courageous and triumphant teenage girl who lives with her/mother, Enide. Enide is encouraging Orva to attend a spina bifida camp to make/friends and develop a transitional plan. Orva, an imaginative girl, loves her/home with her mother and doesn’t even want to think about a transitional plan/at this stage in her life. All seems well on the surface, but what lies beneath/the water are the nefarious machinations of the villainous Vodnik. Vodnik, a/deleterious sea soul, is obsessed with becoming a powerful sea god. To complete/his transition into a god he needs to acquire something special he has never/known: courage. He thus maniacally seeks to steal one thing and one thing/alone: Orva’s courage. Vodnik enslaves Merrow, an entrancing mermaid who has/befriended Orva, and tries to exploit their friendship for his own malevolent/benefit. Will Orva's courage be stolen from her? Find out in July 2015! Besides/telling a compelling, enchanting story, the play’s message is that persons with/disabilities, specifically Spina Bifida, are empowered and autonomous/individuals who have goals, dreams and aspirations. Above all, people living/with Spina bifida have the courage to face daily challenges head-on with/positivity, strength and grace./The play set is being conceptualized, designed and built by Terry Mock, who/has been constructing various sets for the past eight years. Not only will the/set be artistically beautiful, but will function to accommodate characters with/disabilities. The set materials are being funded by a grant received from the/Pennsylvania Rural Arts Alliance. James Walter Elston has created an original/artistic logo for the production. Former college and professional football/coach Ed Jenkins is assisting with graphic design and marketing. Original music/is being written for the play; the production will feature local thespians./The play will be performed on the Greater Johnstown Vocational and Technical/Center stage next summer 2015 on Friday, July 31st at 7:00 PM, Saturday August/1 at 7:00 PM and Sunday August 2nd at 2:00 PM. For more information, ticket/sales, and ways you can help donate toward the cause please visit our website/at www.ultramarinegirl.com. To learn more about this project,/please contact Aspen Mock or Rachel Allen at ultramarinegirl2015@gmail.com
info.risks and challenges: Our challenge is to fund the costs of the production.  Will you help us?/Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: Please help us raise funds for the production costs of a world premiere production of a play that will raise awareness for spina bifida

data.name: Shakespearean Youth Theatre (SYT) - The Tempest

info.description: Shakespearean Youth Theatre is thrilled to be producing The/Tempest as their eleventh production. Every year SYT holds a fundraiser to/raise funds for our production. This year, we decided to put together a/Kickstarter./My name is Victoria, and I am in my fifth year of SYT. I’m/seventeen years old, and I’m playing Prospero in SYT’s The Tempest! /What is the project?/SYT is a theater company for youth between the ages of 13-18 to/put on Shakespeare shows and learn about theater. Every year we get to work/with a professional director who teaches an acting workshop in the Fall and/then directs a Spring production! We get to play famous Shakespeare roles like/King Lear from King Lear, Puck from A Midsummer Night’s Dream,/and Benedict and Beatrice from Much Ado About Nothing.Along the way, we develop a/solid understanding of Shakespeare, grow exponentially as actors, work with/established theatre artists, and create awesome productions we’re proud of./It’s an amazing experience! /The Tempest: /In this year’s play, The Tempest, Prospero (the character/I’m playing!) dwells on an enchanted isle with her daughter Miranda. She is a/sorcerer and the rightful Duke of Milan. Twelve years earlier, the duke's/sister, Antonio, and Alonso, the King of Naples, conspired to usurp her throne./They set Prospero and Miranda adrift in a boat, and they eventually found/themselves marooned on the island. Prospero is served on her island by Ariel, a/spirit who she freed from a tree with magic, and Caliban, son of the witch/Sycorax. When magic reveals that a ship bearing her old enemies is sailing near/the island, Prospero summons a storm to wreck their ship. The survivors make it/to shore in scattered groups. [taken from http://www.bardweb.net/plays/tempest.html] /Our take on it: /We’re setting our play in the early 1900’s,/in an alternate universe where steam-powered technology rules the world. While/there are very real spirits, Prospero harnesses the power of the spirit world/through genius machinery, rather than actual sorcery. However, because there/still is magic in the play, we’re playing a lot with fabric to create effects,/using shadow screens, and what are essentially basic magic tricks. We’re using big/pieces of fabric to create the world, and PVC pipes to create Prospero’s/machinery./We started rehearsals on the 8th of January, and by the/time this Kickstarter is live, we’ll be a little more than a week from opening/on the 25th of February. Aaah! /Where? /We’ll be performing at The Capri Theatre [LINK:/http://thecapritheater.org/], at 2027 West Broadway, Minneapolis, MN 55411/When? /We have a five day run. /Wednesday, Feb. 25, 2015 – 7 pm/Thursday, Feb. 26, 2015 -- 7 pm/Friday, Feb. 27, 2015 – 7 pm/Saturday, February 28, 2015 – 7 pm /Sunday, March 1, 2015 – 2 pm/Who?/The Crew: /Director: Anton Jones/Assistant Director: Suzy/Messerole/Text Coach/Teaching Assistant: Emma Mongoven/Lighting Design: Wu Chen Khoo/Stage Manager: Ben Verdoorn/Costume Designer: Adria Denison/Producers: Ann Mongoven and Patricia Verdoorn/The Cast: /In order of appearance./Master: Cameron D. /Boatswain: Harry F./Alonso: William K./Antonio: Ellie H./Gonzalo: Zoe R-H/Sebastian: Sophie L. /Ferdinand: Isaac J./Miranda: Claire M-L/Prospero: Victoria S. /Ariel: Elisabette F. /Caliban: Josh D. /Adrian: Harry F. /Francisco: Cameron D./Trinculo: Alex C.
info.risks and challenges: There are no risks for this project to be completed - the play will be performed as planned. Since we have a smaller cast this year, there is less money in tuition fees to cover production expenses therefore we are seeking creative ways to raise additional production funds./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter
