data.name: Sea Life by Lucy Catherine at The Hope Theatre

info.description: A darkly comic exploration of life, death and seaweed.“We didn’t call him grandad when we were kids. We called him The Hero. That’s what the whole town called him.”Sea Life is a dark comedy set on the crumbling shores of England, where keeping a tight grip on past and present is as hard as holding back the rising tide. It is written by Pearson Television Writer’s Award winner Lucy Catherine, former writer-in-residence at Bristol Old Vic, and now best known for her work on BBC TV (The Musketeers, Being Human, Frankie), and her Radio 4 plays and adaptations.Sea Life will be the follow-up to The Hope Theatre’s multi award-winning first in-house production Lovesong of the Electric Bear which transferred to the West End in 2015. It is directed by Matthew Parker, Off West End Award nominated Artistic Director of The Hope Theatre.STRETCH GOAL: £2,500.00With a week to go, we've hit our target and we're so grateful to everyone who has been able to donate! As we continue to share the campaign we thought we'd let you know what further donations will go towards: If we can reach £500 on top of our goal we can increase our set and costume budgets, helping our designers Laura and Rachael realise their ambitious plans for the show - including vintage dresses, bespoke coffins and truckloads of real sandwiches. We'll also be able to add one or two additional rehearsal sessions with our full cast during previews - allowing us to fine-tune the show ahead of Press Night!THE PLAYIf your grandad tried to swim the English Channel with a plate of sandwiches strapped to his head, you might think your family was a little bizarre. But what if you didn’t know any different?/////As their sleepy seaside town slips slowly into the sea, Bob, Bob and Eddie are trying to save their neighbours from ending up at the bottom of the ocean. The only thing is, their neighbours are already six feet under."A stunning piece … the humour comes in one colour: funereal black" - The Independent"A quite extraordinary piece of theatre" - The Stage WHAT DO WE NEED AND WHY? We are asking for your help to raise £2,000 to help fund this London premiere production of this fantastic play, which will run from 24th May to 11th June 2016. The Hope Theatre was the first Off West End venue to open with a house agreement with Equity, to ensure a legal wage for all actors, stage managers and box office staff working at the theatre.However, the theatre receives no public subsidy. So to pay our actors and stage management properly, as well as creating fantastic sets and costume, we need to reach out to you.OUR SUPPORTERSWe want to ensure our supporters have the best experience of SEA LIFE, so all backers will be thanked on Twitter and receive regular updates from us on the show. You’ll be the first to know about our casting, see rehearsal photos and more. For those that give a little more we would love to thank you by name in our programme, give you a poster, arrange tickets for performances, drinks at press night, signed copies of Lucy Catherine’s fantastic script, invitations to our Q&A with Lucy and Matthew Parker, and we’ll even organise corporate packages.PRAISE FOR MATTHEW PARKER’S WORK: ★★★★★ “An exciting, magical, odd and touching show that isn’t easy to forget. Unmissable!” – Everything Theatre★★★★★ “Brilliant, absurdist theatre sparkling at every angle… this is intoxicating, mind-blowing theatre” – What’s On LondonOUR TEAMRoberta Vicky GaskinBob Chris LevensEddie Jack HardingDirector			Matthew ParkerProducer			David RalfStage Manager		Jo AbramDesigner Laura HarlingLighting Designer Tom KitneySound Designer Phil Matejtschuk  Costume Designer Rachael RyanCasting Director		Gabriella Shimeld-Fenn
info.risks and challenges: Making fringe theatre is a risk – and because of our in-house Equity agreement and the commitment to emerging artists which it represents, we simply couldn’t afford to make this show happen without your support./However, if we raise our intended amount, the show will go on, and we will be able to deliver all of our reward tiers. The Hope Theatre successfully crowdfunded and delivered its previous in-house show Lovesong of the Electric Bear./The Hope Theatre has proved a successful home for new and experimental writing, and our first in-house show was an award-winning success, with a West End transfer last year. Thank you for reading! We’re so excited to share this incredible play with you, and any support you’re able to give to SEA LIFE is greatly appreciated./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: The Hope Theatre is fundraising for their second in-house show, the London premiere of Sea Life by Lucy Catherine opening 24th May 2016

data.name: University of Utah presents V-Day 2015-The Vagina Monologues

info.description: Calling all Vagina Warriors! Help us produce the globally renowned production of Eve Ensler's The Vagina Monologues!About this project: It’s bold. It’s sassy. It’s fierce. It’s emotional. Hilarious. Sentimental. Thought-provoking. Intelligent. But The Vagina Monologues is more than just a play. It is a conversation, it is a movement, it is a safe haven and it is a revolution to end violence towards women and girls; including rape, battery, incest, female genital mutilation and sex slavery. As part of the V-Day Campaign, this global activism movement is working towards increasing awareness and building a network of strong, educated and empowered women and girls around the world to promote a violence-free living environment through education and recognition. In conjunction with its 15th Anniversary, the V-Day Campaign has launched its most ambitious campaign to date, the largest mass action in human history - ONE BILLION RISING.  /////The concept of the campaign is simple. If we take into account the statistics that 1 in 3 women will experience violence in her lifetime, we are left with the staggering number that over 1 billion women on this planet will be impacted by violence.Over the years, the V-Day Campaign has not only grown substantially, but has reached out to 200 hundred countries where women, men and youth come together to RISE, DANCE, and DEMAND the end to violence against women and girls. /At the University of Utah, it gives us every reason to want to be a part of such successful campaign. Through the production of The Vagina Monologues, we can make a difference in our community. We can be a substantial resource for those in need, and be the change we want to see and feel in our communities. /Please rise with us by supporting us! /Only with your donation we can put on a production of The Vagina Monologues. While the director and the entire cast of the V-Team are all hardworking and dedicated volunteers, our goal is to raise money to pay rental fees for the theatre space, technicians, lighting, sound and three performances.  This is where you come in!  We are asking for your donation of any amount to help cover these necessary  expenses and to ensure we make the most of our V-Day University of Utah Campaign. ////// The Vagina Monologues is scheduled to be on stage on February 20, 21 and 22, 2015 at 7:00 pm, at the Utah Museum of Fine Arts Dumke Auditorium on the campus of the University of Utah. /For more information on the V-Day Movement or the One Billion Rising Campaign, visit:/http://www.onebillionrising.org/http://www.vday.org//THANK YOU for your support and we hope to see you at the performance!/FAQ//Have a question? Please ask the project creator directly.  nap_hegedus@hotmail.com/Join us on Facebook and help us spread the word! https://www.facebook.com/events/1600779480151455/
info.risks and challenges: A challenge we are accepting as an entire team and as individuals who are passionate about spreading the word of the 1 Billion Rising Campaign in our community, is just how much we can do. /As women's activists and now official Vagina Warriors, we have become a resource; an essential part to a specific community in our city./The challenge will be seeing and feeling the difference in our communities. The challenge is seeing and feeling the impact we have made with our event./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: STRIKE, DANCE AND RISE with us at the University of Utah to end violence against women and girls!

data.name: Visions

info.description: Jeden Tag starrt die junge, arbeitslose Kim stundenlang auf den flimmernden Bildschirm. Um sie herum verwandelt sich ihr trister Alltag in eine kunterbunte Unterhaltungswelt, die sich zwischen seichten Kochsendungen, Dating- und Talkshows windet. Dieser imaginäre Zufluchtshafen bietet jedoch nur für kurze Zeit Sicherheit und Geborgenheit: das eigene Wohnzimmer wird zu einem Tatort, indem sich Träume unmerklich in Albträume verwandeln, und der Wahn im Kopf die Grenzen des Bewusstseins überschreitet. Nora Wageners erstes Theaterstück Visions lädt den Zuschauer auf eine teils lustige, teils düstere Reise in die eigenen vier Wände ein, in einen Ort, den man eigentlich mit Alltäglichkeit und Geborgenheit in Verbindung setzt. Doch was geschieht, wenn auf einmal Risse in der Normalität sichtbar werden? Die Premiere findet in der Escher Kulturfabrik statt,wo das „Ratelach“ zum Wohnzimmer ummodeliert wird. Die TNL-Aufführungen werden hingegen, um einen wohnlichen Charakter beizubehalten, ins „Bamhaus“ in Dummeldingen verlagert. Visions wird im Rahmen des 20jährigen Geburtstags des Theaterkollektivs ILL aufgeführt, neben Independent Little Luxembourg (September 2015) und Grexit (Januar, Februar 2016).Regie: Claire Thill   Text: Nora Wagener   Schauspiel: Leila Schaus, Sayoko Onishi, Felicity Grist Choreographie: Sayoko Onishi    Video: Melting Pol   Musik: Emre Sevindik         Regieassistenz: Gilles Seyler  Produktionsleitung: Jill ChristopheProduktion Independent Little Lies (www.ill.lu) in Koproduktion mit dem Centre Culturel Kulturfabrik d'Esch-sur-Alzette (www.kulturfabrik.lu) und dem Théâtre National du Luxembourg (www.tnl.lu).
info.risks and challenges: Independent Little Lies ist ein unabhängiges Theaterkollektiv ohne eigene Räumlichkeiten und ohne Konvention mit dem Kulturministerium. Unsere Projekte sind fast immer Koproduktionen mit Theatern, Kulturhäusern, Festivals, Museen oder anderen Partnern. Wir finanzieren unsere Projekte indem wir Anträge stellen an verschiedene Geldgeber, je nach Art und Ausrichtung des Projektes, wie z.B. an das Ministère de la Culture, das Fonds Culturel National, an diverse Stiftungen usw. /ILL ist es sehr wichtig, die Künstler die an diesen Projekten arbeiten so fair wie möglich bezahlen. Um dieses Ziel zu erreichen, brauchen wir zusätzliche finanzielle Unterstützung./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: Nora Wageners Theaterstück lädt den Zuschauer ein auf eine teils lustige, teils düstere Reise ins Wohnzimmer der jungen, arbeitslosen K

data.name: Action To The Word's DRACULA

info.description: by Alexandra Spencer-Jones/Inspired by Bram Stoker/Making its world premiere at Pleasance Theatre at the EDINBURGH FESTIVAL FRINGE 30 July - 25 August 2014 this production will be highly stylised, with an extreme physical edge and an exhilarating soundtrack performed live.DRACULA is the latest production from acclaimed theatre company ACTION TO THE WORD, an ensemble of artists presenting contemporary adaptations of classic works. Our recent adaptation of A Clockwork Orange ("Imaginative and striking... it sizzles with energy" Evening Standard ★★★★) enjoyed worldwide success after its season in Edinburgh 2012.This initial non-profit production is creatively driven by Alexandra Spencer-Jones (Artistic Director/Writer) and our creative team: Jo Chichonska (Musical Director/Orchestrations), Patrick Gleeson (Composer), Zoe Koperski (Design), Lyndsay Clark (Corset Design), Charlie Morgan-Jones (Lighting Design). WHERE DOES THE MONEY GO?Every pound we raise here will go directly toward what you see on stage: the sets, costumes, props and musical instruments. The money will enable us to enhance our live band instead of using pre-recorded music. Even the costume making is costly - what can we say, 19th century steampunk corsets don't come cheap!Seriously, every single contribution (no matter the size) will make a huge difference to our show. We hugely appreciate your support.FEATURING AN ACTOR/MUSICIAN CAST///Rachel Bright and Jonno Davies (© Matt Martin 2014)///This electrifying reworking of the much loved gothic horror story will feature a powerhouse actor-musician cast of nine including:RACHEL BRIGHT (EastEnders) as Lucy Westenra and rising talent JONNO DAVIES (A Clockwork Orange) as Dracula./CAST LIST/THE COUNT – JONNO DAVIES JONATHAN HARKER – HENRY BAUCKHAM MINA MURRAY/ELIZABETH – OLIVIA BROMLEY LUCY WESTENRA – RACHEL BRIGHT VAN HELSING/HAWKINS - HENRY DOUTHWAITE ARTHUR HOLMWOOD - MARC RHYS RENFIELD – ADAM CLIFFORD QUINCY MORRIS – TOM WHITELOCK DR JOHANNA SEWARD – CLAIRE PETZALTHE YEAR IS 1897 & COMPUTERS CAME EARLYSet in 1897 - but in a world where computers and the electric guitar have already been invented - the narrative follows the original novel, packed with all the horror, the sexual tension and the dark violence it evokes. This swaggering steampunk gothic thrill-ride will feel like attending a rock-concert in the court of Queen Victoria, dragging audiences to hell and back and leaving them begging to be bitten. ABOUT USAction To The Word's recent productions include: A CLOCKWORK ORANGE (Edinburgh Fringe Sellout Show 2011/2012, Soho Theatre, Latitude Festival, Australia Tour, UK Tour, Hong Kong, Norway); CONSTANCE & SINESTRA AND THE CABINET OF SCREAMS (winner 2011 Musical Theatre Matters: UK Awards – Best Emerging Artist Edinburgh Fringe, New Wimbledon Theatre ‘Fresh Ideas’ season); TITUS ANDRONICUS (2011 Edinburgh Festival). Thank you so much for being part of this, we couldn't do it without you. From everyone at Action to the Word!                                                                                                           Lastly, please LIKE on Facebook and FOLLOW us on Twitter or click the SHARE button below our video at the top of this page to help spread the word!
info.risks and challenges: Live theatre is challenging at the best of times and can be full of surprises. But that's also part of the fun and you can judge by our past record we have good people in place to get us to Edinburgh and deliver a first class production./We have contracted with the Pleasance for our Edinburgh season and tickets are on sale. We will also perform 4 preview performances at Pleasance London to iron out any kinks before we officially open./Our rehearsals commence on 23rd June 2014 and the cast and crew have made a commitment of their time and energy until the end of August 2014./Lastly, here is some important legal information:/· Please read the rewards carefully to determine those which are location or date specific. Travel, housing and personal expenses are NOT included. /· Must be over 18 or accompanied by a parent or legal guardian to attend all events. /· Dates of performances are listed on the Pleasance website. If a performance is cancelled we will endeavour to move your tickets to another date. Ticket rewards are not transferrable and do not have a cash value./· Attending of drinks will be subject to individual company member's availability. Once we have set a date, we will give you as much advance notice as possible./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: A thrilling 'steampunk' reworking of the infamous gothic horror novel by a powerhouse ensemble will leave you begging to be bitten.

data.name: Brief Hiatus: Little Deaths 2016

info.description: Brief Hiatus was born out of a desire to create more quality professional theatre in Brighton. A lot more.From classics, contemporary theatre, new writing, Shakespeare, local authors, foreign translations and our own devised work, we are an actor‐centred company aiming to create performances that stimulate the actors and audience equally, and to expose both to a wider range of theatrical experiences./Brief Hiatus also aims to create high quality work at low ticket prices so that everyone can have access to the theatre, whether they are fans of ours, students or just walk‐ups who come to see what's on. We are a Brighton-based theatre company formed in November 2015 with the aim of creating diverse, challenging works for local regional theatres. Our first production was Howard Barker’s Gertrude - The Cry in March/April 2016, which received an ‘Outstanding Show’ from FringeReview.com. Since then, we have planned a further three shows for our 2016 Little Deaths season, as well as our #VeryLittleDeaths season - the first of which launched alongside this crowdfund. We have also recently launched a video project - Shakespeare’s Wake, a collection of monologues, sonnets and other homages to Shakespeare’s work in honour of the 400th anniversary of his death, produced and performed by local actors, companies, directors and artists in and around Brighton and Hove. With five more productions planned for this year alone, the web series, and our 2017 season already in the works, we need your generous support to keep up our rapid momentum.//We aim to raise £5000 from by July 2nd 2016. We’ve already proved with our past productions, Gertrude and Othello, that we are capable of creating self-sustaining theatre. However, the upfront costs involved with staging a show can be a real setback, and it is increasingly hard for small, new companies in the arts to find the money to fund these costs. In order to stage two full scale productions as part of our Little Deaths season we are asking for £5000.Little Death costs// per production:Play licensing		£90 x 6 performances		£540/Rehearsal print					£50/Marketing print						£150/Online marketing					£30/Rehearsal venue hire	£10 x 50 hours			£500/Theatre hire		£150/day x 6 days		£900/Props/set						£80/Costumes						£100//Total							£2,350We passionately believe that theatre is an essential part of culture that can be used to create a dialogue with the audience, provide a safe access to catharsis, to talk to the future as well as making a historical record and to make magic.Thank you for your time, your trust and your support of the arts.
info.risks and challenges: After we raise the money to fund our Little Deaths season the hard work really begins. In a world dominated by reality tv and talent shows it is increasingly hard to tempt audiences from their living rooms and in to the theatre. We will keep exploring exciting plays to perform and bold ways to stage them, building up our reputation as L'Enfant terrible of the Brighton theatre scene, creating theatre that cannot, and will not, be ignored./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: Actors creating more theatre in Brighton. A LOT MORE. Classics, contemporary, new writing, Shakespeare, foreign translations and more.

data.name: Nude: A play by Paul Hewitt

info.description: We're in need of £2000! (£500 was the bare bare bare minimum we needed to begin.)NUDE, a play by Paul Hewitt. Directed by Ian Nicholson3rd - 21st May at The Hope Theatre 7.45pm/(15 performances) Start time: 7.45pm Running time: approx 1hr with no intervalTickets: http://www.thehopetheatre.com/productions/nudeA new poem-turned play about love and fate – how two strangers can become lovers and how relationships grow and fade endlessly.Heavily influenced by The Ruba’iyat of Omar Khayyam, this original play is an exploration of two people’s love for one another and how fate might play its part. Love grows and fades, nearly always involves two strangers and, like life itself, is almost entirely unexplained. Fate, here, is personified. Fate is someone we all know. Nude was commissioned by Apples & Snakes and was produced by Element Arts as a part of the SO: To Speak Festival 2015 where the play premiered in a 20ft shipping container in Southampton. After it’s run at The Hope Theatre, Nude will transfer to Forest Forge in the heart of the New Forest before heading out on a tour of the South.Nude is produced in association with Forest Forge Theatre Company.CastMichelle Fahrenheim WOMAN Ed Nash MAN Roshni Rathore FATECreatives Director Ian Nicholson Assistant Director Josh Whatsize Designer Minglu WangCompany InformationForest Forge is one of the British leading touring theatre companies based in the New Forest, England. Founded in 1981, the company is known for touring to rural and village communities.Ian Nicholson, director. Ian has directed plays at New Theatre Royal Portsmouth, Bush Theatre, Southwark Playhouse, New Diorama Theatre, The Bike Shed Exeter and The Egg Bath to name a few. Ian is Artistic Director of Old Salt Theatre. Minglu Wang, stage designer. Minglu was a 2015 Linbury Prize finalist.
info.risks and challenges: Due to the late notice of this project, we are under an enormous time constraint to raise the money we need to be able to pay all cast and crew, buy and build the set, cover marketing costs and get the word out about this fantastic play! /It is unusual to have such a short amount of time to advertise and plan for a production such as this, but with your help, it is definitely possible./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: A new spoken word play, written by Paul Hewitt, in 3 parts about love and fate, inspired by the Ruba'iyat of Omar Khayyam.

data.name: Strangeloop Theatre - A Focus on New Works

info.description: A Christmas demon, love French-style, a dead mother legally haunting her daughters – Strangeloop Theatre's entire 2015-2016 season features original work written by Strangeloop company members.  We couldn't be more excited about these brand new scripts hitting the stage, but we need your help to realize these productions.  If you believe, as we do, that the theatre is for taking chances and bringing new stories to life, we hope you'll support our 8th season.“Krampus!,” an original horror parody by Mike Wozniak and Jaclyn Jensen, will fill the annual holiday show slot.  A fun and scary take on family Christmas and the Krampus myth (Google image search this if you have never heard of it.  You'll be glad you did!), it is sure to stand out among the saccharine offerings of the season. "French with Me," Strangeloop's annual Valentine's Day collection of musings on love, will feature all new short pieces by company members.  "Mitera'" by Maria Burnham, will be the spring full production.  A show about three Greek sisters whose mother is still trying to run their lives, from beyond the grave, ''Mitera" contains both fun and poignant moments only stories about family can accomplish.Your donation will help cover production costs like venue rental and marketing, as well as design elements such as costumes, sets, and lighting.  Strangeloop Theatre is a 501(c)(3) not-for-profit.  All donations are tax deductible to the extent allowed by law.Stayed tuned for updates on the shows, playwrights and Strangeloop.
info.risks and challenges: When producing new works, there is always a financial risk.  New scripts by young playwrights, don't have the built-in familiarity to help draw crowds.  Fortunately, Strangeloop has experience putting up new plays. /As an itinerant Chicago company, Strangeloop can afford, in some ways, to take more risks than companies with more overhead.  This is one of the reasons we are pushing to do new works.  Many theatres simply can't afford the risk, and fewer new shows are being brought to life as a result.  Strangeloop raises all funds needed before producing any piece and is not dependent on ticket sales to pay for production./Strangeloop is small but resourceful.  We have been producing in Chicago for 7 years and have always risen to any production challenge. Our company members bring a range of experience in nearly every aspect of theatre, so we are able to adapt in light of setbacks./Here is a little history on past Strangeloop original productions./2009 "The Millionaire Farmer" adapted by Brad Gunter/"...extremely enjoyable for its wit, great performances and good-natured fun. To borrow the play's personifying style, 'Millionaire Farmer' is Charm itself." - Centerstage, Highly Recommended/2010 "The Sound of a Yellow Flower" by Dustin Spence/"...Strangeloop has mounted a thoughtfully directed, efficiently designed, and convincingly acted production on a shoestring." - The Chicago Reader, Recommended/2012 "Shadows and Lust" by Michael Wagman/Chicago Fringe Festival Participant/2012 "What was Mine to Do" by Dustin Spence/Originally presented as a short scene in Loopshop and then developed as a part of the Department of Cultural Affairs new play incubator series/2014 "Thinking Caps" by Keith Gatchel/"All the personal details and dialogue are smart and sweet, and the play touches minds with Vonnegut more than once." The Chicago Reader/Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: Help Strangeloop Theatre create and support new work by sponsoring our 2015-2016 season.

data.name: Jelly Beans at Theatre503

info.description: I was the most beautiful child, everyone always told me how much potential I had.From the director of Theatre503’s recently acclaimed BU21 comes Jelly Beans. Dan Pick’s first full-length play is a brutally honest, hilarious and pitch-black confessional about what happens when every axiom of your life turns out to be a lie.Dan Pick’s fresh and exciting writing reveals first-hand the story of a momentous day in the life of a young man teetering on the brink of self-destruction. As his drab existence isshattered by a violent attack and an escapist binge that sees him running from painful memories and present dangers, can a self-proclaimed hero save himself from oblivion?Jelly Beans considers what happens the moment a young man with a toxic combination of fear, loathing and delusions of grandeur is presented with a very real image of himself in the future, of what he’s doomed to become.Writer Dan Pick comments, 'We’re a generation raised on Disney, riddled with debt, anxiety and depression. We wished on stars as children but the happy endings we were promised seem more distant now than the farthest reaches of our universe. We live behind laptop screens, isolated by the very devices designed to connect us, fed to bursting on a diet rich in reality TV and pornography. It often feels as though we’re all facing our own individual crisis of purpose. And when you realise the happily-ever-after might not be yours?'This one-off limited run is from the creative team and production company behind BU21 (★★★★★- The Stage) and award-nominated Cans(★★★★ - Time Out).Stuart Slade comments, 'Dan is clearly one of the most gifted directors of his generation, and/when he sent me his first play, it became annoyingly apparent that he is, potentially, also/one of the most gifted writers as well. Jelly Beans has a searing confessional honesty to it, a/muscular brutality, but also a totally unexpected delicacy and tenderness. In the hands of the/astonishing Adam Harley it’s a play that sometimes difficult to watch, but always impossible/to ignore.'During our last production 'BU21' by Stuart Slade, after the literary team read Dan Pick's script, we were asked back immediately. With such short notice we need your help. We are pledging to raise £1,750 to pay our wonderful actor Adam Harley, and our incredible creative team, be able to rehearse properly and bring an excellent play to the stage. We revel at the chance to be back on the Theatre503 stage, but putting on productions takes months of fundraising and planning which we did not have. We hope this will help and we will see you on the Theatre503 stage!Thank you from Kuleshov.
info.risks and challenges: Growing a theatre company in this financial climate and engaging and attracting audiences to new work can be challenging. However, having the support of Theatre503, one of the most exciting and important new writing venues in London, has been invaluable. They have witnessed and nurtured the growth and development of Kuleshov, and continue to give us their support, which fills us with confidence that our work is important and should be shared . We believe in the importance of making and supporting new writing and giving our own generation of writers a voice. We are committed to establishing Kuleshov as a platform for new and important work for the long term./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: Help get Jelly Beans to the Theatre503 stage. An important piece of new writing by Dan Pick, produced by Kuleshov Theatre

data.name: BIRDS (debut play with Hightide) - Response Workshops

info.description: BIRDS - PLAY & WORKSHOPSMy debut play BIRDS has been selected by Hightide to be developed on their First Commissions scheme. As part of the scheme we each apply for Arts Council funding for the development of the play. To gain the funding I have to secure 10% of the overall budget, that's where you come in.... WAIT. DON'T STOP READING. There's more. I don't JUST want to write a play. I want to host workshops for girls ages 13-18 in response to the themes of the play:- unhealthy relationships - self esteem - sex/consent- violence- foster care/family- friendshipsI NEED YOU TO HELP ME MAKE THIS A REALITY.£1500 will pay for: An expert facilitator / Travel / Workshop SpaceIn the workshops we will take sections of the script and open discussions about issues that feel most important to them. Then the participants will produce a creative response to these issues.I WANT TO: raise self-awareness, galvanise discussions, inspire new ways of thinking, boost confidence, and promote creativity! The workshop will run Monday to Friday during a school holiday. And will be FREE OF CHARGE. As my play is set in Nottingham my aim is to run a pilot workshop there and then expand the same format to two sites in different areas of London.I will be connecting with young girls who are most in need of a workshop like this; through local charities, PRUs, secondary schools etc, I will invite referrals based on need.Finally... Some statistics to make you think. Things need to be done. 40% of prisoners under 21 were in care as children. (www.thewhocarestrust.org.uk/pages/the-statistics)Only 13.2% of children in care obtain five good GCSEs - compared with 57.9% of all children. (www.education.gov.uk/rsgateway/DB/SFR/s000930/sfr08-2010.pdf)A quarter of young women leaving care are pregnant or are already mothers and nearly half become mothers by the age of 24. (www.communitycare.co.uk/Articles/2008/01/23/107036/teenage-pregnancies-among-children-in-care-research)
info.risks and challenges: Possible challenges we may face:/Support from charities /Support from local theatres for space /I will tackle these challenges by gathering a cracking team with a wealth of experience in delivering expert workshops for vulnerable people. We aim to produce and provide a water-tight plan that theatres would be interested to back, not only philanthropically but also high quality content, both in creative material and participant engagement./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: 30 days to raise £1500 - to run drama workshops about the plays themes with girls (aged 13-18) who are in need! GIRL POWER!

data.name: Poleroid Theatre Present : FREE FALL by Vinay Patel

info.description: Hello!Thank you for taking the time to watch our video! /Poleroid Theatre want to introduce you to FREE FALL - A dark, funny, and important new play by exciting, fast-rising London playwright Vinay Patel. /////14th October - 1st November 2014Pleasance Theatre, Islington Associate Director | Rebecca Hill/Producer | Chris Snow/////Midnight at the Dartford Crossing; Roland’s settled in for another thrilling night supervising the toll machines; Andrea’s pretty sure she’s come to kill herself. Neither of them wants to be there. Both think the other’s crazy. Still, it’s nice to have company.Two strangers on a bridge in the dead of night, a game of dominoes, and a value ready meal - HighTide Escalator playwright Vinay Patel’s new play explores humanity, desperation and hope./////This is a particularly special project, as it is Vinay's first full length play of to be staged in London, as well as being Poleroid's first three week run of a play in a London theatre./￼Rob Drummer, Associate Dramaturg at the Bush Theatre & ex-Literary Manager at HighTide Festival Theatre said:“Vinay is a passionate and intelligent writer with a real flair for a dialogue as well as structuring/￼ storytelling.”///// ABOUT VINAY (Writer):Vinay was born and raised pretty much exactly on the London/Kent border, leading to a lifelong fascination with the places between places. He has many joyful childhood memories of driving over the Dartford Crossing after experiencing the esoteric majesty of Lakeside shopping centre.He studied for an MA in Writing for Stage & Broadcast Media at the Royal Central School of Speech and Drama, graduating with distinction in 2011. Since then his short plays have been produced at the Bush Theatre, Theatre503, the Park Theatre, and the Brockley Jack Studio Theatre among others and he has won competitions run by IdeasTap, the BBC, the National Youth Theatre and Shine Drama. Vinay was selected for the prestigious HighTide Festival Theatre Escalator Plays Programme and his play TRUE BRITS will be playing in Edinburgh prior to Free Fall./////ABOUT POLEROID THEATRE:In an industry driven by TV talent competitions and 'names' dominating the West End, Poleroid Theatre is a like-minded collective championing new writing, developing the contemporary image of young creatives in the UK and giving this talent a platform through the creation of eclectic, fast-paced, exhilarating contemporary theatre, that tells important, poignant and off-beat stories about young people. Over the past three years we have been lucky enough to have produced theatre and events all over London, Manchester & Edinburgh at venues including Theatre503, Last Refuge, Tristan Bates, Old Red Lion, White Bear, Cockpit, Live Theatre, Hackney Attic and Wilderness Festival with some fantastic emerging creatives from numerous drama schools, schemes and platforms including the Royal Court Young Writers Programme, Old Vic New Voices, Live Theatre Newcastle, BBC 3, Channel 4 and more. Poleroid is given mentoring and space by IdeasTap’s Creative Space and the Camden Collective. Poleroid Theatre is currently a self-funded organisation and relies on campaigns such as Kickstarter in order to operate, produce work and pay artists. ABOUT REBECCA (Associate Director):Rebecca is Director in Residence at the Almeida Theatre, Co-Artistic Director of Unbound Productions, an Associate Director of new writing company Little Pieces of Gold and an Ovalhouse Artist for 2014 as recipient of the Arts Manifesto: A Future for the Artsaward. She has directed in venues including Southwark Playhouse, Pleasance Theatre, Park Theatre and Ovalhouse Theatre, and her work as a writer has been seen in venues including Swansea Grand Theatre, Ovalhouse Theatre and the Bush Theatre. ABOUT CHRIS (Producer):Chris runs FreeRange Productions and is Assistant Producer for Snapdragon Productions. Credits include Travesti (Edinburgh Fringe), The Dead Wait (Park Theatre), This Was Your Life (UK Fringe Tour), Thark (Park Theatre), and The Three Faces of Doctor Crippen (Edinburgh Fringe).ABOUT MOLLY (Artistic Director of Poleroid): Molly is an Acting graduate of the Guildford School of Acting and Artistic Director / Executive Producer for Poleroid Theatre. As an actress she has worked in television (BBC/Channel 4) and theatre (Theatre503/Live Theatre). She is also Associate Producer for Third Man Theatre and has Assistant Produced for Nabokov Theatre. Her producing credits include: FlickBook (Theatre503/Etcetera); Back2Back (White Bear); Breakout (Cockpit); Write It : Mic It (Hackney Attic Regular / Castle Hotel Manchester); Peanuts (Tristan Bates/Last Refuge); Instadate (Hackney Attic/Ritzy Cinema); Our Father (Theatre503); Timebomb (White Bear); Nabokov Arts Club (Vault Festival/Nabokov Theatre). She is currently producing Mugs Arrows (Old Red Lion/Third ManTheatre); Free Fall (Pleasance Islington); The Allotment (R&D, Live Theatre Newcastle); and new comedy series Flat 32 with Channel X TV Productions.///// WHERE YOUR MONEY GOES:- Paying our team a fair wage for the countless hours they'll work on the project.- Designing and installing an exciting set, spanning different locations to fully serve the play.- Investing in the marketing of the production, spreading the word to the public and to members of the industry.- Our Rehearsal Rooms and admin costs./////To find out more about what we do, reviews and images, check out our website: www.poleroidtheatre.co.uk or follow us on facebook /Poleroidtheatre and twitter @poleroidtheatreA full budget for this production is available upon request.Don't hesitate to get in touch with us at: hello@poleroidtheatre.co.uk Thank you for your support.
info.risks and challenges: It is so important that we work with the best possible cast and creative team on the project - building our wider team is a vital next step for us./As with all theatre projects, our biggest challenge is to get the show in front of an audience, and to sustain that audience through the run. A lot of that hangs on being able to attract useful press connections and to get strong and consistent coverage./Our team are experienced at managing projects of this scale, and feel confident about achieving our aims. We can't wait to get Free Fall on stage in October./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.name: One-Man Show: "The Book Of oded, Chapter 2"

info.description: YOU DID IT!! YOU MADE IT HAPPEN! THANK YOU! THANK YOU! THANK YOU!///////You'll need an HTML5 capable browser to see this content.//////Play////////////////////////////Replay with sound//////////Play with  sound/////////////00:00///00:00////////////////////////////////"The Book of Oded, Chapter 2" started about 5 years ago when I was working as an animator for Image Movers Digital. At that time I was meeting with Jamie Greene, the Off-The-Couch coach. After hearing that I was missing a creative outlet in my life, Jamie suggested writing and the first few pages of my story were written.Almost 4 years later, in an acting  class at LifeBook Acting, run by Allen Levin, I brought some of that material and performed it in front of the class. The response was so positive and encouraging ,that I immediately got back to the writing and completed what now is a one-man-show./////With the help of Yafit Josephson, a fellow actress and performer/co-writer/co-producer of the critically acclaimed One-Woman Show "NEW EYES", I was introduced to Sammie Wayne, IV. An award winning director that came on board and took the writing to a whole new level.My life partner, Oscar Ibarra, asked to join as the producer, and the dream team was formed.Eight workshop shows later, almost 300 people have seen the show, and the reviews were raving:/"I laughed, and cried... And left feeling inspired and moved by the openness and honesty of the show."/"Congrats to Oded! What a great show! I highly recommend EVERYONE go see this amazing show! You'll laugh, you'll cry, you'll leave feeling jubilant!"/"What a fabulous performance & story. You touched my heart!"////////You'll need an HTML5 capable browser to see this content.//////Play////////////////////////////Replay with sound//////////Play with  sound/////////////00:00///00:00///////////////////////////////////////You'll need an HTML5 capable browser to see this content.//////Play////////////////////////////Replay with sound//////////Play with  sound/////////////00:00///00:00///////////////////////////////// As we passed the 50% in funding our campaign /and the goal seems closer than ever, /I'd like to THANK:/Daniel Camp/Socorrow Ibarra/Matt Murphy/Eugene Nova/Mosh Bar/Joleen Nordstrom/Forrest Curran/Runjeev Ignatius/Chuli Joy/You are making it happen!!!!!/www.HelpTheBookOfOded.com////////// Oded Kassirer was born and raised in Tel Aviv, Israel. After graduating from Art College where he mastered in video production and editing, he moved to Los Angeles to start a 16 year career as an animator. In the last 6 years he worked with Image Movers Digital, owned by Robert Zemeckis,on motion-capture movies such as "Polar Express" and "Beowulf". 2010 was the year of the "Change" when the pursuit of creativity led Oded, at first, to Second City and from there to LifeBook acting academy. In the short time he has been acting Oded achieved many roles in movies, music videos, national commercials, stage plays, as well as appearances on Jimmy Kimmel Live and the Eric Andre show.///// Sammie Wayne, IV is an award winning Actor and Lighting Designer. He is also a Stage Manager and Director. Since 2010, he has garnered five NAACP Theatre Awards, two for acting and three for lighting design. In 2009, he received Best Supporting Actor for “One Woman Two Lives”, directed by Denise Dowse. In 2013, he received his second Best Supporting Actor for Ana Lucasta, directed by Ben Guillory. He received Best Lighting Design for Loretta Devine’s “Pieces of Me”, Vicki Lynn Reynolds, “Hattie:What I Need You To Know” and Celeste Bedford Walker’s “Camp Logan in 2011,2012,2013, respectively. He directed several episodes of America’s Next Top Model Cycle 20. He has a B.S in Computer Science, from DePaul University. Before his career in entertainment, Sammie was a Computer Programmer and Software Engineer for General Motors and Northrop Grumman.///// Oscar Alef Ibarra is debuting his very first theatre stage production as an executive producer. Oscar is not a stranger to working in the entertainment industry; He was introduced to the arts at an early age when his mother enrolled and encouraged him to perform in countless plays and recitals for the LAUSD. After high-school he took a break from acting to work and master the art of DJ'ing where he produced and collaborated in several music tracks. Recently Oscar decided to take on the world of Film and TV working behind the scenes taking on various roles, from production assistant to location manager. Oscar A. Ibarra has recently written a short film Called "My name is David" which he will be producing and directing, due out at the end of 2014.//////And so, encouraged by the amazing response, we decided to bring the show to a full production run of 6 weeks and 18 shows, at the Working Stage Theatre in Hollywood, which is why we  need your help with the production costs. Here is the breakdown of the $10,000 we are looking to raise:///// Choose the reward that you like best and then use the safe and secure  Amazon payment.////////// My heartfelt Thanks to all of you who pledged in these first 48 hours! It's important to the campaign to have a strong start! You're helping me fund my dream, and that is truly amazing! Keep spreading the word, www.helpthebookofoded.com and I'm sure we'll reach the goal!/Hannah Rosenthal /Mike Alahouzos //Jennifer Joyce //Randy Vinneau/ Rivka Henchinski Weissberg /Elad Sharon/ Chad Kukahiko/ Christianne Sainz /Gustavo G Salas /Edward Jowdy /Erin Elizabeth Muir /James Quiett//////Oren 'Squeegee' Rehany,  Ben Kenber,   Amichay Mazor,                   Dan Frischman,   Andrew Sherman,    Sharon Spence,   Sarah Vitorino/Lorri Quiett,   Leilani Marie Smith,   Aaron Garcia,   Keith Rand,        Aliza and Gideon Mazor,   Mark DiCristofaro,   Stu Maddox,            Israel Orly & Harel
info.risks and challenges: There are two main challenges with this production:/1. We want to make the most professional presentation which includes stage design, lighting, audio and direction./2. We want to get the word out there thru promotion so that the theatre is full each and every show with theatre loving audience, ready to be inspired and entertained./I know that with your generous help we can bring this show to many more people and inspire them with this story of coming out, relationships, dealing with inner-demons, and finding love in the most unlikely of places./The main pillars of the show are Mortality, Acceptance and Love which are universal and can touch each and every one wherever they are./Thank you! TODA RABA! Gracias!/Oded/Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.name: Pretty Butch

info.description: What does it mean to be grey in a world that only recognises black and white?Five characters navigate life on the fringes as they grapple with gender definitions, whether by choice or by circumstance. At best, society disregards them. At worst, they are relentlessly harassed—even viciously bullied—for being different. Inspired by the true stories of women (and men) who relate to being butch, Pretty Butch examines feminine masculinity that is often hidden from everyday life and explores the diversity of butchness through the experiences of different people who defy gender conventions.Pretty Butch, an M1 Singapore Fringe Festival 2017 commission, was developed in residence at Centre 42, under the Boiler Room and the Basement Workshop, a programme for new works and works-in-the-making.Pretty ButchVenue: Black box, Centre 42, SingaporeDate: 11th - 14th January 2017Click here for more information about the show Click here to purchase tickets for the showWhat Pretty Butch means to usThe label Butch is a problematic one. Traditionally, its connotations of hyper-masculinity seem to suggest a complete lack of femininity and hold people who subscribe to the label to unrealistic standards. However, our ideas of masculinity and femininity have evolved over the years. Is being butch only skin deep? Or does being butch point to something closer to the core of the individual?Based on interviews with people, research and personal experiences, Pretty Butch unravels what it means to be butch, and why perceptions of masculinity and femininity still hold sway in our world today. This project aims to honour butch identifying humans, celebrate the uniqueness of butch identity and maintain the visibility of the community.Through a style of theatre that is intimate, the performance aims to challenge the audience’s assumptions about butchness, allowing different audience members to find their own entry points and draw their own conclusions from watching the show. The production is driven by a very human need for love and acceptance. We hope that this production touches people, whether they identify with being butch or not.About our team///Meet the Pretty Butch team!                                  (From L to R: Henrik, Richelle, Farah, Shannen, Fadhil, Deonn, Liting)///We are a group of freelancing professional theatre-makers who have each brought our own unique styles to collaborate on this work which deals with issues very close to our hearts.Written and Directed by 		Tan Liting Performed by 			Deonn Yang, Fadhil Daud, Farah Ong, Henrik Cheng, Richelle South, and Shannen TanLighting Design by 			Helmi Fita Sound Design by 			Jing Ng Production Stage Manager		Merissa Tang Assistant Stage Manager		Natasha MayPlaywright and Director - Liting works full time as a theatre practitioner with an interest in devising performance from personal stories. Liting’s past directorial credits include Eulogy (bae Collective), The Truth About Lying: Heresy and Common Sense for the Theatre (The Finger Players), Taking The Subs (The Substation Director’s Lab), (When I’m) Sixty Four (Ageless Theatre), Re: Almost Left Behind (Singapore Arts Festival 2011), Almost Left Behind (NUS Thespis). Liting likes conversation, hearing and telling a good story. Liting also likes guitars, sneakers and referring to Liting in the third person. Liting is also a founding member of Theatre Cell.Deonn Yang - Deonn was born and raised in Singapore. A graduand from LASALLE College of the Arts with a BA(Hons) in Acting, her recent theatre credits include: The Hummingbird (dir. Edith Podesta), a commissioned work by Zizi Azah, Revolutionary Model Play 2.0 (dir. Wang Chong) commissioned for SIFA 2015, 4.48 Psychosis (dir. Natalie Hennedige), and Holidays (dir. Chen Ying Xuan) with Take Off Productions. Deonn hopes to use comedy to affect change. She also enjoys wearing button-down shirts.Fadhil Daud - Fadhil first dabbled in theatre in 2009 when he joined the drama club in his junior college, after which he attended and graduated from Buds Youth Theatre Programme in 2015. Currently undergoing the Bachelor of Arts (Theatre Studies) programme at National University of Singapore, his recent theatrical involvements include an assembly school programme by Teater Kami, a kids musical by The Rice Company Limited and Crossroads by Theatre Today. Fadhil has also worked on some commercial film projects, working multiple times with Little Red Ants Creative Studio.Farah Ong - Farah is a multi-disciplinary artist - actress, performance artist and an occasional art-maker - who is constantly working towards an organic diversification of her artistic vocabulary. Majoring in Fine Art Photography during her time in LaSalle College of the Arts, Farah has performed across Asia and the Middle East and her photography works were exhibited in the Stockholm Pride Fringe Exhibition. Having come from a strongly rooted background in theatre, she is now exploring the cross-disciplinary practice of photography and performance, which has materialized in her collaborative and solo performance art pieces. She feels that sometimes love makes us numb, culture turns us characterless and religion leaves us being faithless, so her personal practice navigates around their inter-relatedness and contradictions.Henrik Cheng - Henrik is a theatre actor/director/practitioner from New York City via New Orleans. This past year he collaborated with ‘Speak Cryptic's the Tribe’ as part of the SIFA's O.P.E.N., Alamat Bahru by the Wright Assembly, and will complete training at the Intercultural Theatre Institute (ITI) in 2017. It is Henrik’s strong belief that his theatre making should be healing, proactive, and provide hope.Richelle South - Born and raised in LA, Richelle holds a degree from UC Irvine. She has studied under greats such as Donald McKayle & Janet Jackson’s choreographer, Joseph Malone. She performed as a principle dancer with Jazz Spectrum Dance Company, on the national tour of Care Bears by VEE productions and with Disney/Vista Productions. She also performs in drag as Papa Cherry and founded the longest running queer drag King show in Los Angeles – BENT.Shannen Tan - Shannen is an actor and Psychology & Theatre Studies student at NUS. She has worked with theatre practitioners such as Peter Sau in ‘Candlelight’, Felipe Cervera in ‘Furthest North, Deepest South’ and Natalie Hennedige in ‘U.N.I.T.S’. She also recently acted in ‘Long Weekend’ as part of the 20-something Theatre Festival. Currently, she intends to publish her thesis on the psychology of acting titled ‘To Be or Not To Be: Effect of intensity of emotional memory on acting performance and its aftereffects on the actor'. She is very excited to be a part of Pretty Butch and to contribute to the growth of local theatre.Helmi Fita – Helmi is a full-time theatre practitioner and arts educator. He has worked with various theatre companies both locally and internationally. With almost 26 years of theatre experience under his belt, Helmi has worked as an actor/performer, director, production manager, stage manager, lighting designer and technical manager. Helmi was given the Honourable Mention for Special Achievement in Lighting during the 3rd DBS Life Theatre Awards in 2003. Currently, he loves creating and working in Taiwan.Jing Ng – Awarded with the National Arts Council Scholarship in 2011, Jing graduated from Rose Bruford College (UK) specialising in Performance Sound. He has a keen interest in sound design for theatre and dance; and enjoys collaborative, devised and experimental works. Singapore credits: Silly Little Girl and The Funny Old Tree, Titoudao, A Fleeting Moment, Grind, Lord of The Flies, The Truth About Lying. UK credits: Little Black Book, Corpus Christi, Orion’s Hat, Rites & Regulations, Ghost Sonata, The Bacchae, You Me Bum Bum Train. Nominated for Best Sound Design in the 2014 Off West End Theatre Awards for Outfox Productions’ Corpus Christi (UK).We need your help!In order to see this project to fruition, we need your help. Our total estimated budget for this production is $17,000. Based on current fundraising efforts, we have raised $8,000. But we have exhausted all official governmental grant options and we need your help to raise the remaining $9,000 to ensure a professional quality for the show and also to ensure that everyone involved will get a decent wage. 100% of the funds will be used to support the production in the following ways:Creative Fees ($11,000) Everyone involved in this production will be paid equally, on a profit share basis. This Creative Fee budget of $11,000 will be set aside for fees for the people involved in this production. Production Expenses ($3,000) Our production expenses can be broken down as such: /Set Budget: $600 /Lighting Budget: $600 /Sound Budget: $600 /Costume Budget: $600 /Transport: $200 /Welfare: $400 /Rehearsal Space rental ($1,500) Every production needs a rehearsal space in order to ensure that quality work can be produced in a focused and contained environment.Administrative fees ($1,500) On the administrative side of things, we can break down the budget loosely into: /Marketing: $1,000 /Insurance: $200 /Archival: $300/What you getAs a little thank you for donating so generously to our cause, we have a couple of different gifts prepared for you, based on the rewards tiers listed on the right./A meal from our friends at The Garden Slug, Dough Empire, FRY Rooftop Bistro & Bar and Bar NKD (for use in Singapore only, sorry!)/Exclusive silkscreen printed Pretty Butch t-shirts, tote bags and underwear!////Pretty Butch silkscreen printed T-shirt/// ///Pretty Butch silkscreen printed underwear (boxer brief if you prefer)/// ///Pretty Butch silkscreen printed tote bag////A copy of the Pretty Butch full script, autographed by the playwright and cast/An invite for two (2) to our thank you party to meet the cast and creatives, to find out more about the process as well as the personalities behind the work/A 3-hour drama workshop/programme tailored for you and your friends/colleagues (up to 12 people in total) focusing on drama skills for team building, public speaking or just pure, silly fun!/We'd like to thankM1 Singapore Fringe Festival, Centre 42, Bar NKD, FRY Rooftop Bistro & Bar, The Garden Slug, Dough Empire, Ladies District and Two Queens Asia for their support!And YOU! for helping our dreams come true.
info.risks and challenges: Every new theatre work is a labour of love. It is an experiment that sees several different individuals creating something together. Differences and disagreements are bound to arise. However, our team of seasoned professionals and fresh new faces are resolved to work through these challenges and solve problems together by tapping on our experience or adopting new ideas. /We believe that the greatest risk we face in the event of being unsuccessfully funded is for the show to not be of the standard we are hoping to achieve. It would be a pity if we allow for the further erasure of the butch identity by not properly honouring the stories that need to be told./We need to speak up and we need your help./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.name: Vieux Carre: from Binghamton, NY to Provincetown, MA

info.description: But we need YOU to help us get/there.  And we've got less than 5 DAYS to reach our goal!For the final show of our 2012/2013/season, KNOW Theatre, of Binghamton NY, produced the little-known and/rarely-performed Tennessee Williams play VIEUX CARRÉ. /Our production of VIEUX CARRÉ was a/success, word spread, and soon we got a call from the folks who produce The/Provincetown Tennessee Williams Theater Festival on Cape Cod in Massachusetts,/with an invitation we couldn’t refuse: “We’d like you to bring KNOW’s/production of VIEUX CARRÉ to our September 2014 Festival in Provincetown!”/////An invitation to perform for the/world at an international festival right here in the U.S. And only seven hours away!/For a small theatre like KNOW, going to Provincetown is a huge opportunity, and/because it won’t require expensive air travel, it’s actually within the realm/of possibility. The Festival’s invitation came with the offer of financial/assistance – enough to cover roughly one quarter of our expenses – and we’re/grateful to our new friends in Provincetown for their generous subsidy. We knew/we had little time to raise the other 75% of our production and travel budget,/but we took the plunge!  We said, ”Yes, we accept your invitation! KNOW/Theatre will be thrilled to perform at The Provincetown Tennessee Williams/Theater Festival!” We’ve got some serious fundraising/to do. /That’s where you enter the picture...
info.risks and challenges: VIEUX CARRÉ has a big cast – ten actors – and the complexity of our production demands more than just a stage manager, so we’ve budgeted for two technicians as well.  Add the show’s director and the total comes to 14 – fourteen company members who will spend a total of eight days traveling to and from Provincetown and rehearsing and performing at the Festival.  Housing is being provided by the Festival, but meals are not – with the exception of buffet receptions on our first and last days in Provincetown.  /It’s been more than a year since our original production of VIEUX CARRÉ.  We’ve had to recast a few roles, including the hiring of two Equity actors from New York.  KNOW has never employed Equity actors before, and a guest artist contract, though modest in compensation to the actor, is a big step up in expenses for us.  /Our plan is to rehearse and perform VIEUX CARRÉ again, here in Binghamton, in late August and early September, closing here on Saturday the 20th and leaving the following Monday for Provincetown.  We’ll rehearse in our assigned space at the Festival all week.  We’re performing on the weekend, September 25th, and driving home to Binghamton on the 29th. /We are looking to Kickstarter to help us raise five to six thousand dollars to cover the following festival expenses for the 14 members of our cast and crew:/Transportation to and from Provincetown (more than 800 miles round-trip), and Meal Per Diems for 8 days at $40 per person (a modest allowance for a week in a major resort town during an international festival.)/HERE'S OUR BUDGET.../Van Rental 	$750 /Gas and Tolls 	$450 /Per Diems 	$4,480 / 	TOTAL 	$5,680 /OUR KICKSTARTER GOAL: $5,000 /While there’s plenty more we need to raise, we’ve set a modest Kickstarter goal to be sure we won’t fall short of the threshold necessary to be successful.  Beyond this $5,000 target, we’d appreciate any additional help you can give us.  /Our overall production budget, including the cost of remounting VIEUX CARRÉ in Binghamton, is nearly $20,000./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: KNOW Theatre has been invited to bring our production of Vieux Carré to the Provincetown Tennessee Williams Theatre Festival!

data.name: Gypsy Stage Presents "The Importance of Being Earnest"

info.description: Gypsy Stage Repertory is a touring theatre company based in theDunedin, FL.  It is our mission to break the performing arts out of the confines of a theatre space and back into the world.  By performing in unconventional and nontraditional spaces, we can bring the art of theatre to a new audience who may not have been exposed to it otherwise.This season, Gypsy sticks to that mission with a production of Oscar Wilde's classic romantic farce "The Importance of Being Earnest," like you have never seen it before. In a world that is neither then, nor now, bosom buddies Jack and Algernon are determined to find true love, no matter how many lies they must tell.  It's big.  It's loud. It's gay and debonair. And its covered in techni-color glitter.  The Company Production Director - Brianna Larson; Technical Director - Daniel Hayes; Cast- Jack Worthing-Jonathan Thornsberry; Algernon Moncrieff- Daniel Hayes; Gwendolyn Fairfax- Tia Strachen; Cecily Cardew- Alex Keiper; Lady Bracknell- Danny Ray Polson; Ms. Laetitia Prism- Natalie Sullivan; The Reverend Dr. Chasuble- David Nisson; Lane/ Merriman- Preston Copeland
info.risks and challenges: We are Gypsies in every sense of the word.  We are a community and a family.  We do not have a home performance space but rather travel around making every place a performance space.  This does create some challenges particularly for a large cast, period play like Wilde's "Earnest." All the scenery, props, costumes, and necessary equipment to operate the show must be compact and transportable.  But production director Brianna Larson and Technical director Daniel Hayes believe that constraints such as these can also be the greatest source of inspiration and creativity.  They challenge us to discover new ways of producing work without sacrificing its integrity or production value.  Both Larson and Hayes have extensive training and professional experience in the technical and performing arts, and welcome the opportunity to break out of the traditional theatre mold and discover something entirely new./For this particular production we are attempting to create a world that pays homage to the aristocracy of Victorian England: The luxury, the grandeur, the ceremony.  With out sacrificing that vision, we must also create something that is collapsable and transportable.  Our solution: Trunks.  Old, ornate, refurbished trunks create the furniture of the scene and, on a functional level, provide a wealth of storage space for props, costumes, and necessary equipment./Victorian Era clothing of the 1880s is intricate, decadent, and expensive to recreate authentically, but crucial to the world that "Earnest" exist. To overcome this challenge, we looked to an era of the not-so-distant past for help- the 1980s.  To create Victorian Era garb, we are repurposing 1980s prom dresses which are surprisingly similar in shape and style to the clothing of the Victorian Era.  While the shape and profile of the costume pay tribute to the Victorian Era, the wild colors and fabrics help create the fun, outlandish, imaginary world like no other the audience has seen./As you can see, the challenges that face us with this production are actually opportunities to create something entirely new and do things in a way they have never been done before./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: Oscar Wilde's classic romantic farce like you have never seen it before. Bigger. Louder. Sexier.  And covered with glitter.

data.name: Making the Move--Edinburgh Fringe 2014

info.description: A FIRST PLAY ABOUT A FIRST KISS American Cast, Director, and Playwright Premier New Comedy at Fringe //(EDINBURGH)—MAKING THE MOVE, a new comedy by seventeen year old American Noah Altshuler and directed by Gabriel Weissman, is playing in Just the Big Room at the Caves at Just the Tonic (Nidry Street South/Venue 88) as part of the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, with a world premiere set for Wednesday, 6 August, 2014. In MAKING THE MOVE, two love-struck teenagers brainstorm with their best friends ways to seduce the other, and in the process, explore the pro's and con's of pickup-lines, trickery, and honesty. Todd Rizley (Williamstown Theatre Festival The Front Page, American Repertory Theatre Grief and Surfing) plays Conner, a teen strategizing how to land the first kiss in the middle of his first date with Hannah.  What he doesn’t know is that Hannah, played by Emily Pintel (NYC:  Findlay’s Dream of the Red Chamber), is contemplating a move of her own. The cast of four also includes Daniel Tepper (Williamstown Theatre Festival I’m Listening and Camp Monster, and NYC: Super Sidekick!) and Rachel Geisler (US National Tour of Spring Awakening, and NYC: March and Songs for a New World) who play Stan and Charlotte, best friends and romantic advisors to Conner and Hannah, respectively. Free previews run Monday & Tuesday, 4-5 August, MAKING THE MOVE opens Wednesday, 6 August, 2014, and will run every afternoon (except Tuesday, August 12th) from 12:15 pm to 12:35pm at Just the Big Room at the Caves at Just the Tonic. For information and the most up to date performance schedule, please check the MAKING THE MOVE website at www.makingthemove.co. //MAKING THE MOVE is a witty and charming comedic exploration of the complicated world of teenage friendships, love, and identity.  The play examines a crucial fifteen minutes in any person’s life—the moments before the first kiss—capturing the universal truths and humor of teenage vulnerability and young love.The production makes its international debut at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival and represents the first professional production of a work by seventeen year-old playwright Noah Altshuler and the first Fringe performances for the American cast. TICKET INFORMATION//Tickets (£2, 2 for 1 passes also available) for MAKING THE MOVE are available by calling the Edinburgh Festival Fringe Box Office at 0131 226 0000 or online at http://edinburgh.justthetonic.com/performances.php?eventId=88:460.//A limited number of Free Preview tickets will be available for performances on August 4th and August 5th. PERFORMANCE SCHEDULE//•	ALL PERFORMANCES RUN 12:15 pm-12:35 pm/•	FREE PREVIEWS:  MONDAY, 4 AUGUST & TUESDAY, 5 AUGUST/•	OPENING PERFORMANCE:  WEDNESDAY 6 AUGUST/•	SECOND PRESS PERFORMANCE:  THURSDAY 7 AUGUST/•	REGULAR PERFORMANCES 6 AUGUST THROUGH SUNDAY, 17 AUGUST/•	NO PERFORMANCE:  TUESDAY, 12 AUGUST MEET CAST, DIRECTOR & PLAYWRIGHT//•	FOLLOWING PERFORMANCES ON TUESDAY, WEDNESDAY AND THURSDAY 5-7 AUGUST, 2014, CAST, DIRECTOR & PLAYWRIGHT WILL MEET FOR Q&A at LOCAL PUB (LOCATION TO BE ANNOUNCED AT SHOW) FROM 1PM TO 2PM.
info.risks and challenges: With an outstanding cast, fantastic director, and a story/script that is fun, witty, and thoughtful, MAKING THE MOVE, is ready for its world premier at the Edinburgh Fringe on 6 August, 2014./And while our penmanship is not great, we love to write postcards./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: A first play about a first kiss, Making the Move is going to the Edinburgh Fringe festival.  Join the party, fall in love.  Help us!

data.name: Cancel The Sunshine

info.description: ABOUT THE PLAY Cancel The Sunshine is a new autobiographical play by Chantelle Dusette. It's a piece that aims to shed light on issues surrounding mental health in the context of modern living./“Monday morning. I survived the weekend.” /  Honest, raw, and with sharply observed humour, this is an account of a woman’s struggle with her painful past, inadequate present, and her unquenched desire to find happiness whilst living with a mental illness.  This vibrant, fast-paced piece comes to life through frank, witty storytelling that tells us of music filled tube journeys, self obsessed friends and spiralling nights outs in this constantly evolving and sometimes stifling city of London./CTS is a beautifully poetic and bold piece of uncompromising and urgent theatre.  This production aims to give a voice to those muted, those who need to be heard./ 10% of all ticket sales will be donated to The Amy Winehouse Foundation which the production proudly supports- www.amywinehousefoundation.org ABOUT THE THEATREThe Hope Theatre's artistic director Matthew Parker proudly champions new writing in this fringe venue that describes itself as 'the little theatre with big ideas.' It is also one of the few venues that are committed to the fringe agreement, guaranteeing actors, stage managers and lighting designers receive at least the minimum wage. Each production must also have a one to one with Equity to ensure everyone is happy and that the project is running as planned. HOW YOU CAN HELPThis is a self funded production and we have been able to cover the initial costs thus far but we need your help!  As you can imagine the costs of putting on a theatre production are high, and your generous contribution to this play will help directly towards paying our ACTOR, the THEARTRE HIRE, REHEARSAL SPACE, SET, BUILD and PROPS.The amount we are looking to raise is the minimum required to put this play on the stage in front of an audience. However, with greater contributions we will hope to take this play further a field. This is not a vanity project for us, we are passionate about the subject matter and want to take this play as far as we can to encourage discussion around mental health. The more funds we raise, the further we can take and spread our message./Whether you want to donate a 'High Five', or pledge to have the production come to you, we hope you'll find a donation level that will suit your pocket. Check out the pledges on offer, and feel free to get in touch if you have any questions. THANK YOU! Scott, Chantelle, Maya and all the CTS team :)
info.risks and challenges: As with any theatre production there are potential risks involved, from designing to selling the show. However, we have a strong team with a wealth of experience who have been able to create an imaginative piece of work that we hope will make great viewing for our audience.  /We appreciate that this is a subject that requires sensitive handling, and have been careful to present the writers voice (as this is autobigraphical) with authenticity.  In addition we have also been researching the subject and have presented a sharing of the play after a workshop in order that we would recieve feedback to make the necessary changes to enhance the piece./This is a new company, however, members of the team have worked together in the past and everyone involved is passionate about the subject matter and have given their all every step of the way./Deadlines have been set and met to ensure as smooth a process as possible, with everyone contributing and sharing ideas./We are excited for the opportunity to present work around a topic that needs urgent discussion, in an incredibly reputable theatre that supports new writing.  We are excited to show what can be done in a black box with a lot of imagination, talent and heart./THANK YOU again for taking the time to look at our project and supporting 'Cancel the Sunshine'. We are thrilled to have you as part of our team and for sharing this journey with us and look forward to seeing you at THE HOPE THEATRE!!/Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: Cancel The Sunshine is a new play that explores living with a mental health condition in an honest, witty and articulate way.
