data.name: The Frida Kahlo of Penge West

info.description: Right.  Chris Larner (that's me) has been, as actor, songwriter, director and writer, creating theatre for many years.  As an actor I was the idiot Clingfilm in London's Burning, if that's of any interest.  I wrote songs for, and appeared on stage with comedy legends The Right Size.  Two musicals (both written with Mark Stevens) The Translucent Frogs of Quuup and On The Island of Aars, won awards and plaudits at Edinburgh.  My one-man show An Instinct for Kindness, which tells the story of my accompanying my ex-wife Allyson, to Dignitas in Switzerland, has won awards and acclaim both Nationally and internationally.  All of this: reviews etc and my full CV on www.chrislarner.comThe Frida Kahlo of Penge West, is a two-women play by me.  It will rehearse in June this year, and play at the Rosemary Branch theatre, Islington, http://www.rosemarybranch.co.uk for the first two weeks of July.  Here's the blurb;A two-woman play about one woman's struggle to stage a one-woman play about Frida Kahlo, with two women in it..When quiet, retiring Zoe agrees to let an old university chum sleep on her sofa for a couple of nights, little does she imagine how much her life will be blown apart.   Vain, driven, narcissistic Ruth is an unemployed actor and REALLY CROSS with it.  She decides to do a play of her own, and drags Zoe with her, kicking and screaming, with hysterical results.  Wickedly funny, caustic and absurd, this is about two women driving each other to the extremes.  The Odd Couple meets Resevoir Dogs, but with big laughsWelcome to the world of madcap passion, betrayal, political correctness, wigs and bad, bad Mexican accents.Credits; Director: me.  Producer: Kat Portman.  Cast: Cecily Nash and Laura Kirman, two VERY funny young actresses.  Design: Nina Patel-Grainger. Lighting design: Celia Dugua.  Costume: Natalie Pryce.This is gonna be very, very funny, although Frida Kahlo fans may want to look away, now.  Anyone wants to pledge a hundred quid or over, gets to see the script to see how I've made sense of all that.  We can just about stage this show - with everyone getting a pittance and not eating - for about eight grand.  It'll be tight for that.  The team on design, costume, lighting, etc are all young, highly talented, enthusiastic women at the starts of their careers.  Marketing and publicity are vital and have to be paid for, as does the set and costumes.  The aim is to tour the show in the Spring of 2015, and to that end we need this initial production to be as sharp as possible and get good reviews. Eight grand covers the basic costs.  Twelve grand makes it much easier and we can eat.  Fifteen grand and everyone gets paid properly.  The venue seats sixty and we're on for twelve performances.  If we sell out the finances ease somewhat, but it's still a squeezeI've applied for Arts' Council funding but it's anyone's guess.  And even if the Arts council cough up, it will not, in any case, cover the full cost of the production, and we won't know until 9th July: day one of rehearsals.  This Kickstarter money of three grand will pay for set, costumes, and the wages of a stage manager to run the show.  It's only a start of the money needed, but there's a full-on, outrageous show at the end of it.  Anything else you care to know, email me: chris@chrislarner.orangehome.co.uk
info.risks and challenges: Lack of funds means corner-cutting, delays and frustrations on all manner of things; publicity, set-build, actors having to temp instead of rehearsing, bailiffs at the door, having to rehearse in a cupboard somewhere.  Kat Portman's experience as a producer, and mine as a director and writer ought to be able to steer this production through the choppiest of waters, and see it through to a successful tour, next year.  But money lubricates the whole business../Any work of theatre is a risk.  We have a great script, a team talented and more enthusiasm than a spaniel in Springtime.  BUT - people may hate it, come opening night.  I'd be surprised if that were the case, but they may.  It's a risk I and the whole team are willing to take/Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: Production of wickedly funny new play for two women, written by iconic songwriter and ex-London's Burning man, Chris Larner

data.name: The Tutors

info.description: ThankYOUthankYOUthankYOU for visiting our project page. You are one of the select individuals clicking on something with sentences and paragraphs instead of a cat gif. This is just as awesome. We promise.Before you leave, we'll answer the questions that you’re DYING to know before you take that BuzzFeed quiz.Who are we?We are Battalion Theatre Company. Born in early 2014, we are a group of young actors, directors, producers and artists who came together to follow the fun to the truth of the human condition. The founding members are: Kullan Edberg, Dan Gonon, Gadi Rubin, and Gerrit Thurston. In April 2014, we put on The Understudy by Theresa Rebeck at HorseTrade's Under St. Marks Theatre. In May, we were asked to remount the production at The Kraine Theater. After starting a residency with HorseTrade in the summer, we put on Adam Bock's The Drunken City in September. Through November and December we workshopped and produced a reading of a new play, When I Started Dating Men, by Ryan Trout. In March 2015, we are putting on The Tutors by Erica Lipez; directed and produced by Gadi Rubin.What's different this time?The PlotNew York. 2007.3 years after the social network to rule all social networks was founded. Three recent college grads find themselves stuck when forced to take on day jobs as tutors and online essay editors in hopes of fueling their own social networking startup. With a student blackmailing two of them and work invading the subconscious of the third, these three friends might just be in over their heads.The CollaboratorsThrough our first two productions, we have joined forces with set designers, lighting designers, casting directors, stage managers, and more who believe in our work and want to help us produce amazing productions. Hooray for collaboration.MoneyMoney? Oh yeah. Our first show was done completely out of pocket and we pretty much entirely financed our second show as well. We like to say that we "paid a lot of money to do what we love." This time we want to do things a little differently and give audience members SO MUCH MORE than what they'd expect in terms of production value. Perhaps more importantly, a major priority for us is to pay everyone involved a little something - getting paid for what you love to do is amazing. (It's the least we can do for those who are locked in a theater for multiple days straight with us, as amicable as we are.)Umm, okay, what do you need the money for?/Royalties/Set Design/Rehearsal Space/Artists/We are a young group but we are committed to paying all of our artists for their time, hard work, and brilliant skills. We believe in investing in the people we are so lucky to create with-people who deserve to tell their families and friends that they were actually paid to do what they love, even if it wasn't much.Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can't contribute financially at this time, we still love you and would be thrilled if instead you could:/Come and see the show! TICKETS//Like us on Facebook. /Follow us on Twitter./Follow us on Instagram. /Cry out to the rest of the world that Battalion Theatre and this campaign exist. /Volunteer with us! We're small and always looking for extra sets of hands and skills. If you want to create and are without an outlet, send us an email.
info.risks and challenges: As young theatre professionals, we risk everything by making our own work. Production delays, rights acquisition issues, technical mishaps, and Hurricane Sandy have all beleaguered past productions. /We hope that having the funds to put on amazing shows leaves a significant impact on the audience and inspires them to return to our next shows, building a new generation of theatre followers./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: 3 college grads struggling to fund their social network. 1 bratty blackmailing student. 1 dreamy Asian business man. 1 awesome play.

data.name: To Kill a Machine

info.description: To/Kill a Machine is a new full length play written by Welsh writer Catrin Fflur/Huws. It is an empowering and heartbreaking story of a man guilty only of knowledge,/homosexuality and refusing to live a lie who was turned into a hero, vilified/for his sexuality and suicide and resurrected to hero after his death./“Turing’s life work was/the development of some of the fundamental ideas of information and computation, which underlie the subject.  Plausible and/technically-accurate depictions of science on stage are extremely rare, but/they are extremely helpful to bring the subject to life in the minds of/students and their parents.  Moreover, anchoring a technical subject into/the web of human experience and history (especially British history) gives a/far more healthy and holistic view of a subject that can be seen as very narrow/and geeky.” Simon Peyton Jones, Computing at School/“both/play and production are highly impressive, boding well for the future of what/appears to be an ambitious new company” Othniel/Smith/“It is well known among/the computer science community that Turing’s influence is much deeper than his/time spent at Bletchley Park but these aspects are rarely seen beyond that one,/albeit, fabulous story.  It is/particularly helpful to place such pioneers in the context of a real human/story that our children can, hopefully, identify with.  I am sure that this play will be relevant and/attractive for many school teachers, pupils, undergraduates and the like.  Decent portrayals of science, maths and/computing are rare in our theatres and such work seeking to heighten awareness/of the work and impact of Alan Turing is to be welcomed.” Simon Humphreys,/National Coordinator Computing at SchoolWhat is the play about?/////The play examines the life of/war-time code breaker Alan Turing examining his pioneering work considering/whether a machine could think. The play asks the question what then is the/difference between a human and a machine? And if a human is prevented from/thinking, does he then become a machine?To Kill a Machine does not shy away/from the truth of his story - his homosexuality, the injustice of his/conviction,  the brutality of the/chemical castration, his treatment by the government following his conviction/through to his only very recent pardon. Nor does it shy away from the/complexity of Alan Turing’s brilliant mathematical mind and instead embraces/his work about machines and places it at the heart of the play.You can visit our website here. Or/like us on facebook and follow us on twitter "The tension is mounting here on To Build a Machine. Can the/interrogator crack the code? Will the contestants keep their secrets? It's time/to play on. It's time to play - Imitation". To Kill a Machine, Catrin/Fflur HuwsSo/that is the play, what else does the project involve?Not only do we want to tour the play/but we are committed to promoting the life, work and legacy of Alan Turing/beyond the play. We want to share the amazing stories of Alan Turing – throughout/his life, and also the impact that his work continues to make to the day. His/achievements during the war were incredible but there is so much more and we/want to share that – through workshops, talks, debates, on-line discussions,/hackathons, tweetups, blogs, articles. Basically anywhere there is a platform/to talk about we’ll be there – talking about our play and talking about Alan/Turing. "'Dip the apple in the brew let the sleeping death seep through' Half of/it poisoned. The other half is not. Snow White will eat the poisoned apple of/course" To Kill a Machine, Catrin Fflur HuwsThe story so farIn 2012 Catrin Fflur Huws went/to visit Bletchley Park with her computer scientist husband Jim Finnis and/looked around an exhibition of Alan Turing – his life and work at Bletchley Park./She had been selected for the Sherman Cymru and Aberystwyth Arts Centre Spread/the Word project and had to write a short play. She chose to write a short play/about Alan Turing. She was particularly inspired by/the story of a man being elevated to a hero, vilified and then resurrected to a/hero after his death, she then read his article,  Computing Machinery and Intelligence (Turing,/A.M. (1950)) in which Turing begins by asking two key questions: what is the/difference between a man and a woman and what is the difference between a man/and a machine. In addition to that Catrin is a law lecturer at Aberystwyth/University which adds yet another dimension of her interest in performance and/law and using real trial transcripts to create work – the court scene in the/play is based on a real transcript of a trial for Gross Indecency. Her short play was selected for/a reading – but that wasn’t enough. She decided she needed to write the play/into a full length play and she sought out a producer which is when/Scriptography productions became involved. //////It is no accident that we are/called Scriptography – To Kill a Machine was the start of the company and it/will always be at the heart of the company and in respect of Alan Turing and/the many ways he changed our lives we named the company Scriptography. Aberystwyth University’s/Computer Science department were holding a centenary event celebrating the/birth of Alan Turing – they invited us to perform a reading of the play as part/of it. Since that first reading they have remained committed to the project and/BCS Mid Wales paid for the very first programme which included articles about/Turing’s work – mathematical patterns in nature, artificial intelligence and/the Turing Machine.  The play was produced as a pilot/– in 8 days because that was all we could afford to do. Angharad Lee joined the/company as director, actors Gwydion Rhys – who had the overwhelming task of/bringing to life Alan Turing in just 8 days, alongside Gareth Bale, Ceri/Murphy, Stephen Marzella and Thomas Middler who joined as our male ensemble. It/seemed an impossible task – to mount a complex play featuring historical scenes/alongside a game show! But not only did we do it – Rupert built an incredible/set and we created a soundscape too. It was first performed at/Aberystwyth Arts Centre who also provided rehearsal space.  We were also invited to perform it at Sherman Cymru Foyer. In looking for possible/other places to perform we approached Sybil Crouch at Taliesin Arts Centre –/though they didn’t have space she put us in touch with Arnold Beckman in/Swansea University’s Computer Science department. Arnold was arranging a/science cafe centenary event and invited the play to be performed at it. /////It was that performance to an/audience of computer scientists and ardent Alan Turing fans where we realised the/potential of this play by Catrin Fflur Huws and with  Angharad /as director.  Not only a great/play but a play that computer scientists would embrace, a play that would/instigate discussions, a play that would do justice to the legacy of Alan/Turing. A play that told the story of Alan Turing the way he would have wanted/it to be told. Here are a few reviews of that/early pilot production/http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/wales/posts/play-about-enigma-codebreaker-alan-turing-to-coincide-with-centenary-celebrationsReview by Amanda Clare, Lecturer in Computer Science,/Aberystwyth University/http://amanda-clare.blogspot.co.uk/2013/06/review-to-kill-machine.htmlReview by Othniel Smith/http://blakeson.blogspot.co.uk/2012/11/to-kill-machine.html "My feelings, my love was blind. They could discern no/difference between a love for a man and love for a woman." To Kill a Machine, Catrin Fflur HuwsWhat do we want to do next?In the last few years we have/continued to develop the play with Catrin, though it was already a unique,/innovative play we supported her in developing it, adding a few new scenes to/the biographical scenes including a great scene about Alan Turing signing up/for the National Guard and integrating fully the bizarre game show into the/play.Not only that but Scriptography/Productions has been producing more plays, creating more work, supporting other/writers and building itself into the company that could do justice to this/great project.In 8 days and with minimal/budget we achieved something incredible – imagine what we could do with more/rehearsal time, a decent production budget and a production and marketing staff/to support it. We already have a tour of Wales/booked including Arad Goch in Aberystwyth, Theatr Brycheiniog, Torch Theatre,/Taliesin Arts Centre, Blackwood Miners Institute, The Miners and Theatr Hafren.In addition we will be taking/the play to Arcola Theatre in London and then later in the year we will be/presenting the play at Edinburgh fringe festival where we will be able to invite venue programmers from around the UK and festivals throughout/the world. With your support we can get the/play out there, we can get reviews, we can get more tours booked./////This is the story of a play, a/writer and a company being brought to life and we are especially proud that it/with such an incredible story as that of Alan Turing, the man, the work, the/legacy. A man whose life was cut tragically short but whose legacy continues to/impact throughout the world. We hope that you will want to support us and/follow us on this journey. /“I would/have said that I love you and that I adore you and that you mean the world to/me. And I would have said why did you have to die and why did you leave me and/I love you and I love you and I love you. Ever since that night looking at the/stars.” To Kill a/Machine, Catrin Fflur HuwsWhat are the costs/involved in the project?The costs includes the costs of paying actors, director, writer, producer, designer of the set, lighting and sound, music composed/especially for the project, it will build a set, make the props and/costumes.  It will pay to hire a van to/tour the project around the country and a stage manager and technician to tour/with the show. It will cover the costs to design and make leaflets and posters,/it pays for people to promote the project. It will pay for everything involved/in rehearsing, producing and the tour in Wales and London from the petrol in/the van to the silver spray to paint the set. /“Just tell the court/what it wants to hear, and you're a free man Alan. You can carry on with your/work. You can even carry on with your life as long as you're careful.” To/Kill a Machine, Catrin Fflur Huws/What will the money do/for the project?The project (rehearsals and tour of Wales and London) will cost £38,000 in total, taking the show to Edinburgh will cost another £20,000 and we are raising money from many different sources. Pressure on arts funding is immense at the moment and so we have diversified the way we are raising the money as much as we can to create a sustainable financial framework for the project. However if we can raise at least £8,000 here then we can match fund that from other sources. The money raised/will allow us to rehearse, and produce the project, it will cover the costs of/the initial tour. This will get the project seen and establish a reputation/which will then allow is to sustain the project to keep touring it with all/costs covered by fees paid. Basically this campaign will launch it and beyond/that its future will be for as long as there is an audience for it and so/theatre venues who want to book it.
info.risks and challenges: Creating a great arts project, especially a new play is always faced with challenges – achieving our funding goal is the main one. Without support and funding from a number of sources the project can’t happen but we have put a great strategy in place, we are keeping costs low, realistic but low and we are working on a number of options to ensure that our financial requirements are met./We are a new company so we’ve ensured we have the right expertise to get us through. We have also sought collaborations and partnerships – Arad Goch is a co-producer who will provide rehearsal support, technical advice, marketing advice – basically anything we need to know they can help us with. In addition we are an associate company at Aberystwyth Arts Centre and can call on their vast experience of all aspects of arts production if we need it. /We are a new company though and with those risks come some advantages – we are going to be innovative, we are going to be positive, we are going to take risks, we are going to approach things in a new way because we think taking risks and facing challenges is good. /We think risks and challenges can lead to creative approaches, can lead to innovative breakthroughs./After all Alan Turing took risks and he faced challenges and we want to be inspired to do things the way he did./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: An empowering play about war time code breaker Alan Turing which tells the real story of a hero vilified for his sexuality and suicide.

data.name: Rose of June

info.description: About the project'Rose of June' is being performed at The Unity Theatre, Liverpool in September 2014. It is supported by the of the Making Art scheme, but we are in need of a little bit of funding to make this production awesome!  Roses of June is based on the 5 stages of grief drawn from the company’s experiences and the Kübler-Ross model.Using our own experiences and through the study of these stages we hope to create a beautiful and reflective piece of theatre. We are a company of three actors and one director and are all emerging artists trying to find our way in the wonderful world of theatre!To present these motifs the narrative follows the central character Sam and how he copes with loss and the effects on others around him, specifically the two other characters Emily and Daniel.//We want to explore a different approach to theatre making inspired by the creative processes of Mike Leigh. Although Leigh works with a script, he does not share this with his actors until later in the process. Instead, in the rehearsal room, he builds characters, events and the world in which they inhabit through experiments and improvisational exercises. It is only when he feels this world has come to fruition that he adds the script which is the final layer. We feel this methodology is the most effective way to achieve a raw truthfulness on the delicate subject of grief.//However, to make the process more organic there will be no conventional script in our production, but will develop speech through a series of events using the 5 stages of grief.
info.risks and challenges: We have our rehearsals booked and our venue ready to go, we're even coming up in The Unity Theatre's lovely little 'what's on guide,' but we don't have any money! In order for us to achieve our goals for this project we have applied for arts council funding, but that is only possible if we are successful in sourcing 10% ourselves - which is where you come in!/Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb:
'Can you ever find acceptance in death?' 
Rose of June is a piece of theatre exploring the stages of grief. Unity Theatre - September

data.name: The Promise

info.description: Welcome to our debut project!A year ago, two friends stumbled upon a beautiful and scarcely performed play and thought about how amazing it would be if they could bring it to life. The story follows three teenagers - Lika, Marat and Leonidik - who survive the savage winter siege of Leningrad, 1942, losing everything from their past but gaining each other. Together, they find a new love which unites them, and a new hope which keeps them alive; the promise of a better future.A Little Bit About Us..Those two friends we mentioned are us, Eleri and Laura, and we are the co-directors of the brand spanking new theatre company Equapoise Theatre. The boring bit; Eleri was awarded a First Class Honours Degree in Drama and Screen Studies at the University of Manchester before training on Drama Centre London's two year Screen Acting Programme. Laura did her undergraduate degree in Business Studies before deciding to pursue theatre, achieving a diploma in Musical Theatre and a Masters in Advanced Theatre Practice from The Royal Central School of Speech and Drama. Between us we have several years of performance and production experience, ranging from events such as the Llangollen International Music Eisteddfod, Insight Film Festival, and a variety of Arts festivals in the UK and Ireland.We decided to form Equapoise Theatre as a means of creating our own opportunities alongside providing platforms for other emerging artists to showcase what they can do. As you probably know, starting out in the Arts Industry is far from easy, especially because of the competition for scarce funding from well established companies. However, we think the best way to counteract the challenges the industry can present is to create work we are passionate about through a collaborative ethos, and hopefully inspire others to join us in our efforts. We also intend to take our projects outside London as, although travelling incurs costs and presents challenges, more needs to be done to support and encourage regional theatre. We hope to reach young people and new audiences in the way that we were originally inspired as young creatives, in our home towns of Chester and Galway, which is why we are taking The Promise to Manchester and teaming up with The Boathouse in Barking. It's difficult to be unique and original without gimmicks, which is why with us, what you see is what you get, and we hope that our backgrounds and experiences, and those of our colleagues, will come together to make exciting work that challenges and reaches a national audience. That's enough about us. The Promise So Far..Since Equapoise was formed in February, we have been busy assembling a team of people who are genuinely fantastic at what they do, and its already been an exciting and challenging journey. You'll meet some of the team on our video, but here's a full cast/crew list if you want to check out our individual stories.CrewDirector - Daniel Ward GarberProducers - Laura Marie Donnelly & Eleri JonesDesigner - Isabella Van BraeckelProduction Assistant - Hollie HalesCast Lika - Eleri JonesMarat - Tony EcclesLeonidik - Theo St. ClaireWe've secured three great venues, established the company and launched our monthly new writing night since we started, so things have been pretty busy! Week 1 of rehearsals is over, our marketing campaign is in full swing and this brings us on to the matter of our Kickstarter campaign.What We Need The Money For..We have been lucky enough so far to draw on a small number of favours from people we've worked with previously and some new friends who have become as passionate as we are about this project. We have secured four weeks of free rehearsal space, thanks to Drama Centre London and The Boathouse, Barking who have agreed to become our first sponsor. We are extremely pleased with where we are so far, and have utilised as many resources as we can through sheer time and effort. All the creatives involved are working willingly for free in order to pool the small amount of finances we have into realising the project in its fullest capacity. Personal investment has covered some of our expenses incurred so far in our advertising, and we intend to cover the costs of each venue through the box office revenue.  For this project to fulfill its full potential, we need your support. We still have to cover the costs of;/Travel for the cast/crew to Manchester/Transporting the set and props to Manchester and Barking/Lighting Design/Sound Design/Authentic Costumes and Props/The Copyright for the text/Possible extension to other venues who have declared interest/We fully appreciate how difficult it can be to choose where to invest your hard earned money, but if our work sounds like something you'd like to support and be part of, anything you can give will be gratefully received. This will be the first of many projects for Equapoise Theatre so there will be more opportunities in the future for collaboration, but those who helped us start our journey will not be forgotten!
info.risks and challenges: As with any artistic/financial endeavor, there will undoubtedly be challenges that arise through the risks we are taking in order to pull this project off. Here are some of the potential obstacles we anticipate;/- We will be able to cover our venue costs by selling half capacity at concessionary price in each venue, but we want to be able to give complimentary tickets to industry professionals who might be able to help us take this play even further. As you can never predict how well a show will sell, this is a risk on our part, and we have prepared for this potential outcome by factoring in some leftover budget in case we don't reach the intended ticket sales. If this doesn't happen, the money will be carried forward into our next project as we would rather look forward than keep wages/profit./- We have already faced the challenge of overcoming artistic differences with some people who we had hoped to work with on the project, but eventually agreed that our visions and perspectives were too different to continue. It wasn't easy to reach these decisions, but we have learnt along the way how best to handle such situations and now will be sure to emphasise that we expect collaboration to be at the heart of everyone's attitude to the work. If this were to happen again, our experiences and gut instincts can be trusted to help us move forward in a positive way that best serves the work we are creating./- With every live stage performance, there are any number of things that can go wrong each night, from sound and lighting cues to misbehaving props, costumes and set! We are confident that with our professional training backing us up, and the combined experience of dealing with all sorts of unpredictable problems, we will be able to keep calm and carry on, without these setbacks proving detrimental to the performance./- We have some tight turn around times for getting in and out of each venue, not to mention the transportation of everyone and everything between venues, and only a small team of individuals to make this happen. With travelling comes potential delays, particularly on the roads around London! We have therefore tried to pre-plan our timings to make each experience as relaxed with time as possible and allow for any delays that we might face. We will also be rehearsing the get in and out for the venues as much as we are the text!/If there's anything else, feel free to check out our website and get in touch, we'd love to hear from you!/Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: A play by Alexei Arbuzov about the lives of three teenagers during the Nazi siege of Leningrad, 1942, in a new adaptation by Nick Dear.

data.name: A Hard Rain - New York Debut

info.description: It's the sweltering hot summer of 1969. Cross-dressing, quick-tempered /"Ruby" has been kicked out of the military after a year in Vietnam. With/ no prospects, he winds up in high heels and a rage in Mafia-run gay bar/ in Greenwich Village, where he meets Jimmy: the smart-talking, /vulnerable street kid who will change his world and send him on the road/ to activism.//////"A moving, colorful drama"   /  -The Stage//After/ a very successful run in London in early 2014 at the Above the Stag /Theatre, this script was sent to us in hopes of bringing this local /story to where it all began. It tells the story of a group of New /Yorkers struggling with their identities and societal oppression in the /late 60's. A relevant story with relatable characters, this play truly /illustrates what it is to discover yourself and your values in New York /City. Following a homosexual Vietnam Vet and his relationships with his /friends, lovers, and acquaintances, we see his struggle to come to terms/ with what it is to be./We have spent the better part of a year /streamlining the script and characters to allow them to discover their /true potential, and now we are ready to bring it to the city for its US debut./We have a wonderful venue reserved at the Theatre for the New City, which has a strong history of nurturing new works and their artists. We also have a team of dedicated professionals putting forth their time and talents to keep this moving forward. We just need your help to give this play the push it deserves. /"Packed with sharp gags and vibrant characters. Cracking lines/"/Time Out//5 STARS/"/A fun night out that inadvertently teaches you about one of the most important gay rights movements"/West End Wilma//"A colourful, moving drama." //Paul Vale, The Stage//4 STARS//"Like an East Coast equivalent to the works of Armistead Maupin. This real human drama, with fleshed-out character, natural dialogue and a keen sense of history"//Stephen Bates, The Public Reviews//4 STARS/"/A play with a deeply political heart and resonance for our times... Not only a play with a distinct cultural voice but one with the true potential of becoming something of a contemporary classic. Wonderfully unapologetic, vibrant characters. A lot of fun.-/"/Anna Savva, Whatspeenseen//4 STARS//"A thoroughly involving story."/ QX Magazine//"/A timely, provacative piece. A sharp script which slaps and tickles in equal measure"/Extra Extra//4 STARS/"/A tragi-comic drama. Sharp one-liners. Well defined believable characters, living on the fringes of society"/RemoteGoat//"Bradfield and Hooper have already won over audiences with their acclaimed Christmas shows. A Hard Rain is their first foray into serious theatre – and boy do they mean business... Amidst the drama there is plenty of humour"/Andrew Hayden-Smith, Attitude//"Jon Bradfield and Martin Hooper’s poignant exploration of the circumstances leading up to the 1969 Stonewall riots, and the birth of the modern gay liberation movement... Damaged, but undefeated, Ruby stands for the whole Stonewall generation" //Beige Magazine
info.risks and challenges: We are looking raise an additional $3,000 to assure that our cast, crew, and the play itself gets the attention and appreciation it deserves. /Since this is an extremely low budget production, thus far we have been running on the fumes of good will and as much as we can pull from our own pockets. Over 50% of the $3000 will be set aside just for the cast to make sure they are compensated for their hard work and talents. With this set aside, we will be able to provide them an additional stipend from ticket sales, which they truly deserve. /We are looking to see a return on our investment with the funds from box office sales, but in order to do that, we need to make sure we have gotten the word out. The remaining funds will go towards promotional and marketing materials, advertising in local magazines and newspapers, and cover printing costs for posters and programs. /--What if we don't receive the funding?/If the funding isn't reached, the show will go on, but it could potentially end here. We would love to see this show move further, being picked up by a larger theatre with a larger production budget, so we want to give the best impression possible. Without this funding, the actor's pay and marketing budget would come out of our set and costuming budget, which would in turn limit the environment we would be able to create for these characters. We would hate to have to compromise any element of this project. /Without our marketing budget funded, we may not even see the type of turnout we would have originally seen. Funding this project would allow us to extend our public outreach and bring in those with the capability to produce the play further. You can be a part of that./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: A Hard Rain is a new play that takes place on the eve of the Stonewall riots in the ‘hidden’ gay bars of 1969 Greenwich Village.

creator.name: Michael Luggio, New York Theatre Academy

data.name: Syrian Children's Play: Romeo & Juliet Separated by War

info.description: We need your help to fund this Syrian children's play! My dear friend, Nawar Bulbul, is a Syrian actor and humanitarian. In 2014, Nawar worked with Syrian children displaced by conflict in the Zaatari Refugee camp in Jordan to put on ‘Shakespeare in Zaatari’. Nawar has one objective: To humanize and inspire the children through art. To use art as an outlet for their anger, sorrow, and pain. Acting becomes a place to create meaning and inspiration through creative expression (read about the impact Shakespeare had on their lives).He's at it again with ROMEO & JULIET WITH A UNIQUE TWIST! Seeing the impact and joy that the play brought the Syrian children, Nawar is creating Syrian Romeo and Juliet. Romeo and Juliet are lovers. However, they are separated. Romeo lives in Amman Jordan, and his lover—Juliet—lives in a city inside Syria. The young boy who plays Romeo is an orphaned war amputee having lost his legs before fleeing Syria to seek safety in Amman, Jordan. Juliet is a young girl trapped in a besieged city in Syria cut off from resources, humanitarian support, and her extended family. This is their story of love, longing and childhood. Please help us make this a reality and help us share the beautiful stories of Syrian children with the world. Please note the fundraising goal is $7,000, however I set it at $4,000 as we will not get funding unless we meet the goal.THE BACKGROUND STORY: RESTORING CHILDHOOD THROUGH THE ARTS/In 2014, Syrian Actor/Nawar Bulbul (famous for his role in the popular show Bab Al-Hara) worked with/Syrian children displaced by conflict in the Zaatari Refugee camp in Jordan to/put on ‘Shakespeare in Zaatari’ [Read/more about the production in the New York Times]./The production took/many months to curate and featured 100 children in the cast, handmade costumes,/and a narrative of tragedy all too familiar to these war affected children..///Teaching the children about theatre//////Rehearsals in the refugee camp//////Play time in Amman, Jordan Ampitheatre//////A full house watching Shakespeare in Zaatari!///Bulbul says that psychologically and morally, theater is a way “to bring back laughter, joy, and humanity.” And despite extremely limited resources, he has helped eighty small and dedicated performers and singers find a public voice and platform from which to speak to the world. Nawar's objective is simple: To humanize and inspire the children through art. Arts/became an outlet for their anger, sorrow, and pain. Acting became a place to/create meaning and inspiration through creative expression. Through acting, the/children were able to create a new reality—they were now actors, not merely ‘refugees’.The creative space brought the children over/the course of months, creating a community to express their childhood and move/away from politics and hurt./The performance/debuted in the refugee camp to parents, guests and other children. A public/performance was later held in the old amphitheatre in Jordan’s capital, Amman. /ROMEO & JULIET WITH A TWIST/Seeing the impact and/joy that the play brought the Syrian children, Nawar Bulbul, has decided to now/create Romeo and Juliet. This play has a unique twist!/Romeo and Juliet are/lovers. However, in the Syrian rendition, they are separated. Romeo lives in/Amman Jordan, and his lover—Juliet—lives in a city inside Syria (location will not be revealed to protect the/security of those involved).  /The young boy who/plays Romeo is an orphaned war amputee having lost his legs before fleeing Syria to seek/safety in Amman, Jordan. Juliet is a young girl trapped in a besieged city in/Syria cut off from resources, humanitarian support, and her extended family. /To emphasis the separation,/anxiety and pain a lot of children face from being separated from their/childhood memories, families and their county, the play will use Skype and/online tools as the main means of communication between Romeo and Juliet. Using technology and skype is a creative way to also illustrate separation of many children from thier families. Skype is integrated fully into the play as they speak to each other and express their love through cameras./It is a story of love./Of passion. Of separation. And of longing. Romeo cannot wait to return to his/loves, Juliet and Syria. /The play will be/streamed to audiences online and via video. The play will debut on March 27, 2015 -- World Theater Day.///Rehearsals have begun!////HERE/IS WHERE YOU COME IN:/We are trying to raise $7,000 USD to pay for the following://Internet/Computer equipment & Basic technology tools (Skype subscriptions)/Transportation for production team/Videography and video editing/Photography /Toys and gifts for children and the families involved//PROJECT/MANAGEMENT/This is a grassroots project and is tied to no political, religious/or social groups. The entire initiative is currently self funded by Nawar with/in-kind support from friends and family./I personally met Nawar (the director and brain behind the/whole thing) on a recent trip Amman, Jordan on my way to visit Zaatari Refugee/camp for a project I was working on. We since became close friends and I am now/helping serve as a partner to him to help get him, his projects, and the/beautiful children of Syria get the funding and visibility they deserve. Arts/and cultural engagement is important not only for the morale of the children,/but also to help highlight the humanity of innocent children impacted by war,/with hopes to get more funding to support their mental health and education.PLEASE DONATE WHAT YOU CAN. SHARE THE LINK AND STORY WITH YOUR FRIENDS AND FAMILY. HELP NAWAR NOT ONLY INSPIRE THESE CHILDREN, BUT ALSO HELP THEM EXPERIENCE THE JOYS OF THEATRE AND ACTING. THEY DESERVE THEIR CHILDHOOD.Please note, I set the fundraising goal much lower as Kickstarter does not give you money if you fall short of your goal. Kindly help us reach our $7,000 goal.THANK YOU!
info.risks and challenges: The potential risks involved include security of children and ability to have reliable internet connection. /Nawar and the entire support team are very sensitive to these issues and have very strong knowledge of all the related potential issues and how to overcome them./As for reliability of internet, we are working to purchase internet air time, and will also use an updated computer and camera to ensure quality./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: A creative art therapy project for Syrian children. Romeo & Juliet are lovers separated by war. Romeo in Jordan & Juliet in Syria.

data.name: Cosmic Fear or The Day Brad Pitt Got Paranoia - EdFringe '16

info.description: A short message from the Brad Pitts:We’re Brad Pitt, and we were making a movie about the climate, one that would give people a mission in life, a calling, one that could save the entire world. That was until we signed the dotted line with company Empty Deck, who it turned out didn't make movies, oh no no no, they made theatre. So, this “Empty Deck”, they now need your help to raise £3,500 to get our show Cosmic Fear or The Day Brad Pitt Got Paranoia to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival this August, all in the name of saving planet earth. /////  Who are EMPTY DECK?We’ve been working together since 2014, and we collaborate with artists and playwrights from around the world to make invigorating theatre that is relevant, daring, and international in reach.We’re one of the New Diorama Theatre’s Graduate Emerging Companies for 2016 having sold out at two Incoming Festivals; we’re Associate Artists at The Other Room in Cardiff; and we were shortlisted for the Peter Brook Award for Emerging Company in 2015, for our ‘stunningly performed and deftly directed’ Then Silence. We still have no idea how Brad found us, but he did and we’re in pretty deep now./ We’ve been working with him to make a multimedia show with lots of big projection (because Brad wanted his face “as big and beautiful as the moon”). Brad likes to call it ‘The Great Universal Love Project’ and its aim is big: to galvanise global consciousness to save the planet before it heats up too much, too quickly./We have a big and proudly international team on the show. See full biographies here and names below://///To make Cosmic Fear so far we've had the kind support of the Danish Embassy, A Younger Theatre, and Room One, the makers of the virtual reality headsets and installations you may have seen at Wonder.Land at the National Theatre. Room One have been extremely generous in providing us with valuable rehearsal space, technical expertise, equipment and other in-kind resources. Now though we need your support to guarantee our show getting up to the Edinburgh Fringe this summer - the largest theatre festival in the world. We need to ensure Brad Pitt doesn’t bankrupt us. He’s very demanding./Please do read on for more info or check out what our Brad Pitts have to say in the video above. Have a look at the glamorous perks on the right. Your contribution - large or small - will be hugely appreciated and go a long way in helping us to resurrect Brad’s career and Save Planet Earth!/Thank you for reading.  ///Preview performance, Incoming Festival, New Diorama, July 3rd 2016///LA is filled with traffic jams under heavy smog, trees are drifting under floods in Bangladesh and in China incinerators are burning holes in the ozone layer. Brad Pitt fears the future. /But Brad is a man of action; he’s not just here to entertain, he's here to make a difference./Paralyzed by the coming “Ecocalypyse” - or “Greenhouse-hell” - three flat-mates are left with only one thing they can do: embody Brad Pitt and make the ultimate blockbuster that can transform the consciousness of the entire world and Save Planet Earth! /Cosmic Fear or The Day Brad Pitt Got Paranoia is written by the award-winning Danish playwright Christian Lollike. It marks the anxious unravelling of a mind through three characters as it ruminates on the relentlessly changing climate, and the West's inaction to undo the planet’s devastation.  This is Christian Lollike's UK premiere.///Christian Lollike is also the Artistic Director of the SORT/HVID theatre in Copenhagen. We love what they do..."We challenge your opinions and feelings, and we take you places where uncertainty is the reference point"/// /Directed by Kay Michael (2016 JMK Award Finalist), Cosmic Fear or The Day Brad Pitt Got Paranoia is an absurd multimedia comedy tackling our powerlessness in the face of ever-escalating environmental disaster.  /The show is performing at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival from 3rd – 28th August at 3pm. We're performing at Bedlam Theatre, winner of the Edinburgh Sustainability Bronze Award and recipient of the :entertaining sustainability Award for Venue Sustainability in 2013./ We're proud to continue a shared vision of building a greener world with Bedlam./The Edinburgh Festival is the platform we need for our company’s debut production run, from which we plan to book a nationwide and international tour in 2017./More Than A Show: Cosmic Outreach/Brad was adamant that we couldn’t just do a funny and ironic show about trying to save the planet. That would be mere posturing. We’d also have to organise events and activities that would galvanise people into taking action, in a positive and fun way. //Working in close association with climate change psychologist Dr Stuart Capstick of the Tyndall Centre for Climate Change Research, and with the support of The Vegan Society and various Edinburgh-based environmental groups, we’ve constructed a programme called ‘Cosmic Outreach’, running alongside our production of Cosmic Fear./Our planned events include:/- A Vegan & Veggie Food Tour of the city with an accompanying treasure map//- A Woodlands Workshop with Green Aspirations//- 'Cosmic Cafes’ held in the Bedlam Theatre cafe. These are open forum discussions led by climate psychologists and speakers from GoVeg Scotland. /- /‘Cosmic Commune’ – an opportunity to picnic and connect with the Empty Deck and Cosmic Fear team in the beautiful surroundings of the Meadows, and partake in an afternoon of performance poetry.///"The majority of people, across the world, already accept that climate change is a major threat and might be prepared to support the necessary changes. They currently feel isolated and powerless, but could readily be mobilised if their concerns and hopes became validated within a community of shared conviction and purpose." (George Marshall)/Where your money will be invested/Creating a new show costs a lot of money; it’s unfortunate but true./Your support will provide the final gloss on the production ready for a month long run at Bedlam Theatre as well as our wider outreach programme.// A small amount can go a really long way in ensuring we can get to Edinburgh in one piece, sleep easy at night and feed our hungry mouths. /Your money will go towards the following://•	Props and set. We need to hire a quality projector as well as make a huge projection screen to finish our set for the Edinburgh run.//•	Travel and Accommodation. This includes our own travel costs to and from Edinburgh, and a flat large enough to house 3 happy actors, 1 highly organised stage manager, and a revolving team of Empty Deck producers and creatives. That’s 8 people in total for the month.//•	Marketing. A portion of this money will contribute to flyers, posters and other promotional material. Bedlam Theatre is in a prime position next to Bristo Square, but its capacity is high; an audience of 90. We’re determined to fill those seats. But with thousands of other shows to compete against, our marketing campaign and promotional material becomes vital to our success.//•	Woodland activities. As part of our ‘Climate Outreach’ we’re partnering with Green Aspirations to hold a workshop of woodland activities in the greenlands of Scotland, and we need to hire transport to get groups of people outside of urban Edinburgh and into nature. /Green Aspirations are a woodland based social enterprise who teach traditional crafts and rural skills, from woodland management to whittling. They aim to encourage and inspire a new generation to care for their environment, and we’re thrilled to be working them. /To make the above possible we need to raise at least £3,500...//////Any donation you can give will play a huge part in getting the project to where it needs to be. /Alternatively, if you don't feel able to help financially, that's OK. /Follow us on Twitter, Like us on Facebook, check out our website, share this campaign, and book to see the show in Edinburgh. /Helping us spread the word is half the battle! (Brad is used to global film markets…)/ ////Photo taken by The Other Richard, Incoming Festival 2016///“No play has, or since, embraced the unpredictability of theatre with such schizophrenic dynamism” - Dean Hodge, Freelance Journalist and Reviewer, on Cosmic Fear (scratch performance) at The Other Room //////“Brilliantly directed… Explosive and dynamic…. Certainly want to see more” - Theatre Bubble, on Then Silence  ////// “Terrifying and engulfing” - Exeunt Magazine, on Then Silence /‘Kay Michael has created a non-stop, thrilling physical version of this frightening, intelligent play’ - Andrew Haydon, Postcards from the Gods, on Then Silence/ “Empty Deck is one of the most forward looking and distinct companies I have seen in recent years.”  - Simon Usher, Theatre Director/Thanks so much for reading and we hope you're excited by what we're up to! Please support in any way you can./Team Cosmic Fear x
info.risks and challenges: The biggest risk at the Edinburgh Fringe is always not getting enough bums on seats./In 2015 alone there were 2 million tickets issued at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, so we know that it's a beast of a festival, and there's no hard and fast rule for having a successful run whilst up there - it's competitive./However, we have a large, passionate and experienced team delivering and promoting Cosmic Fear, and have already built up strong partners embedded in the Edinburgh community who share our vision and are working to promote what we're doing through our Cosmic Outreach. These range from our vegetarian and vegan vendors to academics from the Edinburgh University. /On top of this, Bedlam is unique in its commitment to its selected programme of shows. Bedlam has been named one of The Guardian’s Top 10 Performance Venues in Edinburgh and has a loyal fanbase. Being a venue with only one stage, it has a limited amount of productions on every day, so the particular attention and support we'll get from their team will give Cosmic Fear a definitive boost.  Its location on the corner of Bristo Square makes it stand out amongst the other "Big Venues" and is a stone's throw away from the famous Royal Mile where we'll be pulling in our punters via our street publicity stunts. /Our Brads have big personalities so we're sure to make this a hit amongst the crowd. Empty Deck also has various associate companies and artists working across the festival, such as Presence Theatre, and together we're determined to build an audience for bold new international theatre./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: Peter Brook Award Nominees Empty Deck need £3500 to get 'Cosmic Fear or The Day Brad Pitt Got Paranoia' to the Edinburgh Fringe!

data.name: Gore Vidal's THE BEST MAN, by Seat of the Pants Productions

info.description: For the past three years, Seat of the Pants Productions has been mounting innovative theatrical projects with the generous support of the Kickstarter community.You first donated $6500 to help us mount a critically-acclaimed production of God of Carnage, the proceeds from which were used to help raise awareness in local schools to issues around bullying and teen suicide.Next, you bravely supplied $6300 to underwrite the completely original and unique Frankenstein: The Puppet Opera, which was locally composed, orchestrated, played and sung, and then brought to live by local artists and puppeteers who built and operated every object and character seen onstage. Three years in the making - and you were part of it.Last summer, you marshaled $4500 to get Seat of the Pants situated in our new permanent home at The Black Box Theatre in GlenOak High School. Our sold-out performances of Picnic allowed us to start building an organizational savings account that is enabling us to move toward financial independence as we ponder future summer seasons at The Black Box.Because of last summer's success and several received grants, we're only looking to raise $1750 this year for a project about which we're very excited. And we've got just 20 days to do it!Written and premiering on Broadway in 1960, Gore Vidal's Tony-nominated political satire, THE BEST MAN is still witty and prophetic  against the backdrop of the 2016 presidential election. The play pits William Russell against Joe Cantwell as they both vie for their party's nomination during a contested convention. The battle for delegates finds both men courting a countrified former president for his endorsement, managing crises with their respective wives, and fielding increasingly corrupt suggestions from their campaign managers.Skewering both the left and the right, offering biting critiques of how we "do" politics, and raising important questions about character and ethics, THE BEST MAN is sure to be more entertaining than tuning into the actual news.And since art imitating life is always more fun, we're mounting the production July 29-31 and August 5-7, right in the middle of this year's Republican and Democratic National Conventions.We're grateful - as ever - for the support you've shown us along the way, and covet your help again as we strive to bring relevant and exciting theatre to life.Please give at any level you're able and - regardless - please join us for the show. Tickets can be purchase at seatofthepants.eventbrite.com.Thanks so much!
info.risks and challenges: The risks and challenges of this project are fewer than in past years. We've already obtained the rights to perform the show; we now have a year under our belts in a new space that posed some initial challenges; we've proven ourselves several times now in producing quality theater from nothing, and we're moving toward financial independence and solubility. In short, we' ready for whatever comes at us!/Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: Art imitates life: This prophetic 1960 satire follows presidential candidates who stop at nothing to capture their party's nomination.

data.name: The Hat

info.description: Three years ago, on a blustery weekend on the Washington coast, several friends sat around talking about dating stories. One story got the most laughs and caused the most conversation and thus The Hat was born.Admit it, everyone has a story about a date that went bad. Some of those stories make it to advice columns like The Bitter Single Guy. The stories are funny, weirder than real life, and clear heroes and villains. Some of these stories inspired the totally made-up, 100% fictitious, events in The Hat.The Hat has stories about dates gone bad, but there are no clear heroes or villains. Just guys trying to make a connection. Sometimes they succeed. Sometimes they fail. Miserably.Roy Antonio Arauz will be directing an awesome cast: Adam Minton plays Kevin who is looking for love; Charles Waxberg plays the witty Gordon, Jeff Church plays Peter in his mid-life crisis, Eric Olson plays the dashing Markus, Clayton Michael plays the loyal Andrew, and Buddy Todd plays Travis as well as one half of several bad dates. The all-star, all-female design team includes regular collaborators Kim Rosin for set design, Zanna Paulson in lights and Dana Amronin for sound; and the fantastic Natasha Gier takes the costuming reigns. Our Stage Manager will be the amazing David Rodriguez-Jenkins. Additionally, this event will be co-produced by Gay City Health Project.We are thrilled to bring this fun tale to you in April of 2016 at Calamus Auditorium on Seattle's Capitol Hill.
info.risks and challenges: Producing new work is very exciting. This is the first step in what could be a long road. And it’s also very risky. There is no preconceived notion on what the show is about. How to entice people to attend? The show needs an audience to grow, develop and mature. Thus the risk is our challenge: get the show produced, get people to see it./To produce The Hat, aside from our time, expenses include: performance venue rental, rehearsal space rental, costumes, sets, properties, sound design, actor stipends, and last but definitely not least, advertising. Advertising includes posters, cards, website, newspaper and online ads. Is your head spinning yet? All this adds up, and it’s why we would love your support./We are committed to being fiscally responsible when producing the play. Our collaboration with Gay City Health Project has helped us reduce venue rental fees, and we only put on stage what is necessary. Our budget is kept small yet still making sure the play packs a punch. We are being frugal without being cheap./What your contribution helps us pay:/$10 – 1 hour of rehearsal space/$25 – costume budget for one actor/$50 – printing of postcards/$75 – printing of posters/$125 – poster distribution/$150 – print advertising/Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: Six gay men, emotional baggage, and online dating: what could go wrong? A play about looking for love and finding something better.

data.name: The Crusade of Connor Stephens: Professional Play Reading

info.description: The Crusade of Connor Stephens has reached an exciting point in its development, and we're hoping you'll choose to be a part of it!Having been through several rewrites, it is now ready to have a public reading with professional actors in New York City. The reading will be produced in accordance with Actor's Equity Association Stage Reading Guidelines.  The reading is planned for mid-January, 2015. Funds raised through this Kickstarter Project will help ensure Off-Broadway theater rental, payment for actors, and other small necessary expenses such as programs and minimal advertisement. The main goal is to gain exposure for the play, as well as provide the playwright a platform to hear the play read by seasoned actors and make rewrites accordingly in preparation for a full production.Brief SynopsisAnother school shooting has occurred in the US, this time in Texas. The teenaged shooter, Connor Stephens, is hospitalized from attempted suicide. The one victim was Tess Williamson, the adopted daughter of a gay couple — Jim and Kris.  //On the day of the funeral in the midst of national media attention, family members arrive at the home of Jim and Kris to pay their respects. Attendees include Jim's estranged parents, Big Jim and Marianne, and grandmother, Vivi'n. Big Jim, a radical Baptist preacher, is determined to use the current situation as a way of “saving” his son from what he considers to be a life of sin — until it is revealed that Big Jim may be responsible for the death of Tess. //In this intimate family drama, religious beliefs, consequences of actions, and extreme loss shake the families to the core as they struggle to come to terms with the tragedy that has occurred.
info.risks and challenges: If this project is successfully funded, we believe there will be little risk involved in producing the reading. Casting the appropriate actors, given that a number of the performers have older age requirements, could be challenging. But with proper audition notices and agent contacts, this should be easily overcome./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: An Equity Reading of a new play; Intimate drama about a family dealing with consequence of actions after a school shooting.

data.name: Going To Market

info.description: "Going to Market." A story about culture.Devin, a young father and fugitive, escapes his home in Virginia with his 13 year old daughter and takes a job at the Hunt's Point Produce Market. Its his first time in New York City, and things will never be the same. ////Karsten Otto and Chelsea D. Harrison as "Devin" And "Becca"///Our play aims not only to give the audience an exciting story, but also to bring a younger, more diverse audience to the theater. Our team of emerging artists from different mediums have come together stepping outside the theatrical box and creating a multi-platform project that allows audience members to engage in this rich story of community and the struggle of a single father. ////Raquel Chavez as "Camille"///We've been working with StreetLevelCulture and visual artist Nkiruka Oparah, an awesome creative team that focuses on storytelling through fashion and design. They'll be helping us out on every aspect of design from costumes to website to print materials, and will be making sure that Going To Market reflects the feelings and character of the neighborhood. You can see what else they're up to here: http://streetlevelculture.com/ and http://jnkiruka.com We've also been certified by Actors Equity Association to present Going to Market as a Basic Equity Showcase - meaning we have top notch actors who have agreed to work for less pay because they want to bring this new play to the stage.BudgetWe need help filling some gaps in our budget, specifically to make sure we can cover:Rehearsal space rental - $350Costumes and set design - $500General Liability Insurance - $500Transportation for our actors - $200Hiring a trained fight captain (safety first!) - $50Electric and lighting - $200Printing publicity materials - $200Cast Devin............Karsten Otto/ Becca...........Chelsea Villematic Harrison Frank............Michael Mills Domingo.......Randy Nuñez Juan.............David Perez-Ribada Camille.........Raquel Chavez CrewStage Manager.............Wednesday Sue Derrico Dramaturge....................John Gutierrez Costumes, Photography, Art Direction.......Edgar A. Garrido Graphic Design.................Nkiruka Oparah Set, Props..........................Ingrid Larson Fight Captain...................Lindsay Wolff
info.risks and challenges: The risks and challenges of producing theater in Manhattan are many, especially on a low budget. We'll need to stretch our resources without sacrificing the quality of the piece. We want to create something that will create a dialogue that extends beyond the theater. We want to start a conversation. /With your help, we'll put together a performance that will showcase culture and community to initiate a dialogue about what theater can truly mean./Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

data.blurb: Stories from the Bronx make for an uncommon play. Help us finish funding this production, supported by the Kevin Spacey Foundation.
